As Mega Sableye cripples foes throughout a battle, setup sweepers such as Hydreigon and Weavile and cleaners like Choice Scarf Meowscarada find easier setup opportunities to KO foes on the other team.

Mixed Wall (Ghost).description: Mega Sableye is a staple on bulkier Ghost teams due to its Dark typing, great abilities before and after Mega Evolution, and great defensive stats. Knock Off hinders Chansey and Porygon2 for Mega Sableye's wallbreaking teammates and eases the matchup against Landorus and Nidoking. Due to Sableye's meager HP and need for longevity, Recover's a must-have utility option, further enabling Metal Burst. Protect allows Sableye to Mega Evolve safely, ensuring it can utilize Magic Bounce later into the game. Metal Burst retaliates against Fairy-types such as Mega Diancie, while Dazzling Gleam eliminates Mega Sableye's passivity in front of Hydreigon and Roaring Moon. Will-O-Wisp in conjunction with Prankster renders physical attackers like Mega Gallade, Dragonite, and Mamoswine less threatening. The given EV spread avoids a 2HKO from Life Orb Nidoking's Earth Power, assuming Mega Sableye uses Knock Off after the first Earth Power. Mimikyu threatens Dark-types such as Mandibuzz, Galarian Moltres, and opposing Mega Sableye. Gholdengo checks Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant as well as preventing foes from removing entry hazards set by Froslass and Galarian Corsola. Blacephalon handles opposing Gholdengo and utilizes Choice Scarf to clean through Steel, Ghost, and Psychic teams once Heatran, Mega Sableye, and Galarian Slowking, respectively, are removed. Skeledirge has great synergy with Mega Sableye, appreciating the prevention of opposing Stealth Rock and in return walling Volcarona, Mega Lopunny, and Alolan Ninetales.

Sun Setter.description: Torkoal provides great support for Fire teams thanks to its ability to set sun and Stealth Rock as well as remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Lava Plume can potentially burn offensive threats like Dragonite and Iron Hands. Body Press allows Torkoal to use its great physical bulk to its advantage by threatening Dark-types such as Roaring Moon and Tyranitar. Heat Rock allows Torkoal's sun to support teammates for longer, but Heavy-Duty Boots can also be used so that Torkoal can switch in more freely without fearing entry hazards and have an easier time removing them. Yawn is an option that pairs well with Stealth Rock because it forces switches. Volcarona makes for a great partner, as it appreciates the sun Torkoal sets so that its Flamethrower can hit new benchmarks, notably OHKOing Landorus and 2HKOing Empoleon and Alolan Muk after a boost, as well as now being able to survive a Hydro Pump from Choice Specs Greninja to set up one Quiver Dance. In return, Volcarona is able to deal with Fighting- and Ground-types such as Kommo-o, Swampert, and Great Tusk thanks to its coverage. Cinderace threatens Normal- and Rock-type foes such as Porygon2, Ogerpon-C, and Hisuian Arcanine and can don a Choice Scarf to dispatch speedy threats such as Choice Scarf Iron Treads and Tapu Lele. Heatran deals with problematic walls such as Toxapex and Archaludon by trapping them with Magma Storm and removing them with Earth Power as well as Diancie with Flash Cannon. Heatran also runs Stealth Rock so that Torkoal can opt to use another option such as Yawn. Late-game sweepers and cleaners such as Mega Charizard X, Ceruledge, and Blacephalon appreciate the sun Torkoal provides so that they can mop up more efficiently.

Offensive Dragon Dance (Dragon).description: Mega Altaria's unique typing and offensive potential allow it to serve as a valuable setup sweeper that checks threats like Kommo-o, Roaring Moon, Iron Hands, and Keldeo. Pixilate-boosted Return checks the aforementioned Dragon-types as well as Fighting- and Dark-types such as Terrakion, Mega Sableye, and Mandibuzz. Earthquake is essential coverage, as it hits Steel- and Fire-types like Heatran and Magnezone and—in conjunction with Return—eases the Dark and Electric matchups. Roost increases Mega Altaria's longevity so it can continuously Dragon Dance throughout the match or use its bulk to switch into threats. The given EV spread allows Mega Altaria to survive Mega Lopunny's Triple Axel. Choice Specs Kyurem is a great teammate, as it breaks past the likes of Toxapex, Corviknight, and Dondozo for Mega Altaria. Garchomp sets up Stealth Rock and Spikes, wearing down Mega Altaria's switch-ins. Kommo-o breaks past Steel-types like Skarmory, Aegislash, and defensive Celesteela as well as other troublesome walls like Toxapex and Hippowdon for Mega Altaria. Roaring Moon threatens obstacles such as Mega Diancie, Choice Specs Greninja, and Skeledirge.

Calm Mind (Dragon).description: Calm Mind Mega Latias excels at sweeping Fairy, Electric, Normal, and Ground teams thanks to its immense bulk and unique resistances. Stored Power eventually breaks through Unaware users like Quagsire and Clodsire after three Calm Mind boosts, and it is immediately strong after one boost thanks to it being a STAB attack. Thunderbolt wears down Celesteela and Mantine more efficiently. Ice Beam is another option and allows Mega Latias to OHKO Mega Garchomp and Landorus without needing boosts, making it an effective check to these threats. Alternatively, Refresh helps Mega Latias shrug off Toxic from threats like Clodsire and Tapu Koko, preventing it from being stalled out. Using Mega Latias can be a liability due to not being able to run the Dragon-immune Mega Altaria, so teammates like Archaludon and Hisuian Goodra that can stave off Dragon-type attacks are mandatory. Archaludon also helps Mega Latias by setting Stealth Rock to chip down Celesteela and Corviknight, taking on Triple Axel users like Meowscarada and Weavile, and being able to check the aforementioned Mega Altaria. Hisuian Goodra deals with Fairy-types like Mega Diancie and Tapu Lele, checks Gholdengo and Heatran, and annoys Celesteela and Ferrothorn with its coverage and ability in Sap Sipper. Kommo-o breaks down Steel, Normal, and Dark teams that Mega Latias has difficulty with, and in return, Mega Latias deals with Toxapex, Clodsire, and Mantine, which usually check Kommo-o with ease. Physical setup sweepers like Swords Dance Garchomp and Dragon Dance Roaring Moon form a wallbreaking core with Mega Latias, as they take care of the Steel- and Psychic-types that Mega Latias struggles with like Celesteela and Mega Gallade. Choice Scarf Roaring Moon or Latios provides speed control and deals with threats like Kommo-o, Mega Charizard X, and Iron Valiant.

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description: Choice Scarf Latias is an effective form of speed control on Psychic teams, differentiating itself from other Choice Scarf users like Tapu Lele and Iron Boulder with its excellent utility options such as Healing Wish. Latias's part-Dragon typing alongside Levitate lets it switch into and threaten many Electric- and Ground-type attackers such as Alolan Raichu and Landorus. Trick is preferred over Defog, as it allows Latias to shift its Choice Scarf to special walls like Ting-Lu and Blissey that would otherwise trouble it. However, Defog can be used over Trick to allow it to clear entry hazards for its teammates thanks to its great Speed. Healing Wish lets Latias stand out from other Choice Scarf users by allowing it to give one of its teammates a second chance in battle. Victini is a fantastic teammate for Latias because it that helps break through Steel-type Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Skarmory. Similarly, Mega Gallade can support Latias by breaking down Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon such as Heatran, Hisuian Goodra, Tyranitar, and Ting-Lu. In return, Latias can provide Healing Wish and Defog support for both Mega Gallade and Victini, check Zapdos for Mega Gallade, and check Ground- and Water-type Pokemon such as Garchomp and Ogerpon-W for Victini. Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is an excellent teammate for Latias, threatening Dark-type Pokemon such as Mega Sableye and Weavile. Jirachi is also a great teammate because it can deal with Fairy-type Pokemon such as Tapu Lele and Choice Scarf Iron Valiant, sponge attacks from Pokemon like Kyurem and opposing Latias, set up entry hazards, and provide safe switch-ins for Latias with U-turn.

Choice Scarf (Dragon).description: Choice Scarf Latias is a premier revenge killer on Dragon teams for its decent revenge killing capabilities, as it's able to outspeed common threats to Dragon teams such as Iron Valiant, Choice Specs Greninja, and Mega Garchomp while providing useful utility options in Defog and Healing Wish. Psychic lets Latias revenge kill troublesome Fighting-type Pokemon such as Hisuian Lilligant and Mega Lopunny. However, Psyshock can instead be used to hit Assault Vest Iron Hands and Clodsire harder. Defog allows Latias to work as emergency entry hazard removal thanks to its great Speed. Trick can be used over Defog to allow Latias to cripple special walls like Galarian Slowking and Blissey. Healing Wish lets Latias restore the health and status of one of its teammates, allowing them to have a second chance in the battle. Mega Altaria and Roaring Moon are superb partners that threaten the Dark- and Ghost-type Pokemon that Latias is weak to such as Tyranitar and Gholdengo. Kyurem is another great offensive partner, as it can destroy threats that Latias struggles against such as Mamoswine and Ting-Lu; in return, Latias can inconvenience special walls like Blissey and Galarian Slowking with Trick, beat Fighting-type Pokemon such as Keldeo and Urshifu-R for Kyurem, and provide Healing Wish support for it to take advantage of. Garchomp is also a great partner that pressures Steel-type Pokemon that Latias struggles against. It can also punish most physical attacks directed at Latias with Rough Skin if using a defensive set, while its Swords Dance set takes advantage of special walls that Latias struggles with such as Blissey and Galarian Slowking. Garchomp can also set up hazards, which allow Latias to OHKO threats such as Greninja for its team. Kommo-o is also a fantastic partner for Latias, as it beats Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon such as Mega Scizor and Ting-Lu while also appreciating Healing Wish support for a second assault. Archaludon is a great partner for Latias as well, as it provides a buffer against threats such as Roaring Moon and Mega Altaria that would otherwise beat Latias or take advantage of it while also setting up hazards for Latias.

Choice Specs (Dragon).description: Latios is one of the most powerful special wallbreakers Dragon has, with its strong STAB attacks that are complemented with a good Speed tier, Ground immunity, and vast movepool. Latios's strongest STAB move is its devastating Draco Meteor, destroying dangerous threats like Kyurem and Archaludon. Luster Purge covers bulky Fighting- and Poison-types such as Buzzwole and Toxapex while the high Special Defense drop chance gives Latios the potential to break through special walls that take neutral damage from Psychic-type moves like Gastrodon. Thunderbolt is an option for Water- and Flying-types like Empoleon and Celesteela, which is complemented by Ice Beam for threats like Sinistcha, Landorus, and Gliscor. Aura Sphere is an option on Latios for Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn that otherwise wall it. Trick cripples common switch-ins like Blissey, Alolan Muk, and Galarian Slowking by locking them into one move. Flip Turn can be used to preserve momentum by allowing Latos to switch out of counters such as Tapu Lele. while also preventing it from being Pursuit trapped by Dark-types like Alolan Muk that can switch in on its STAB moves. For teammates, Latios appreciates both Steel-types Archaludon and Hisuian Goodra switching into Bug-, Ice-, and Dragon-type attacks while providing Stealth Rock and Toxic support, respectively. Archaludon checks Weavile and Mimikyu, while Hisuian Goodra covers Tapu Koko, Greninja, and Tapu Fini. Latios in return removes Ground- and Fighting-types like Great Tusk and Keldeo that threaten them. Mega Altaria provides a Dragon immunity and a Dark resistance, dealing with Hydreigon and Mandibuzz. Garchomp removes Steel-types like Heatran and punishes physical attackers like Scizor with Rocky Helmet while providing Stealth Rock and Spikes. Garchomp and Mega Altaria also benefit from Latios defeating physical walls such as Mega Venusaur and Skarmory. Kommo-o benefits from Latios's ability to break through Poison-types while covering Dark- and Steel-types like Mega Tyranitar, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo for Latios. Roaring Moon is a strong Choice Scarf user, outspeeding and removing threats like Enamorus and Latias. Garchomp, Kommo-o, and Mega Altaria also crucially break through special walls like Blissey and Hisuian Goodra, benefiting Latios further.

Specially Defensive (Psychic).description: Jirachi is a great supporting Pokemon for Psychic teams with its great bulk, access to a variety of utility options, and ability to switch into Pokemon like Corviknight and Mega Venusaur. Iron Head in conjunction with its ability Serene Grace can irritate Pokemon like Alolan Muk, Clodsire, and Blissey. Jirachi can spread status with Thunder Wave to lower the foe's Speed. Stealth Rock is useful to wear down pivots and exert more offensive pressure against Flying, Poison, and Water teams. U-turn allows Jirachi to serve as a pivot to switch in its offensive teammates. Alternatively, Healing Wish can be used to heal its teammates back to full health and remove status. With 124 Speed EVs, Jirachi can outspeed threats such as Mega Tyranitar and Mamoswine to fire off Iron Head or switch out with U-turn. Mega Gallade is a great offensive teammate for Jirachi, as it can threaten out Dark- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Hydreigon, and Heatran. Victini is an offensive pivot that poses a threat to Grass- and Bug-types such as Scizor, Ferrothorn, and Mega Pinsir while also taking advantage of Steel-types that pivot into Jirachi. Slowbro forms a defensive pair with Jirachi to wall physical attackers like Cinderace and non-Choice Band Excadrill. Tapu Lele can threaten out Dark-type Pokemon such as Mega Sableye, Hydreigon, and Weavile. Celebi takes care of the Ogerpon formes and bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Mega Swampert. Latios can make use of Choice Specs to deal great damage to take out threats like Mega Charizard Y and bulky Dragon-types like Archaludon. Latias can be used over Latios as a support Pokemon with Healing Wish that can deal damage with Draco Meteor.

Z-Happy Hour (Psychic).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Nasty Plot.description: Deoxys-S is a versatile offensive threat for Psychic teams due to its coverage and Speed that lets it outspeed even Choice Scarf threats like Landorus-T, easing matchups like Ground, Water, and Flying. Thunderbolt targets Flying- and Water-types like Tornadus-T, Corviknight, and Greninja, and Gigavolt Havoc OHKOes Gholdengo, Scizor and offensive Heatran at +2 after Stealth Rock damage. Ice Beam, in addition to hitting Flying-types, also threatens Dragon- and Ground-types like Hydreigon, Hippowdon, and the Landorus formes. At +2, Energy Ball OHKOes foes like Swampert, Gastrodon, and Mamoswine, which take minimal damage from its other moves. Expanding Force in Psychic Terrain OHKOes bulkier foes like Mega Diancie, Kyurem, and Volcarona at +2. With Shattered Psyche, Deoxys-S can beat these foes without requiring the Psychic Terrain boost. Expert Belt is an alternate option to provide a boost to the various coverage moves that Deoxys-S uses while also relieving the Z-Move slot for a teammates like Tapu Lele or Victini. Deoxys-S appreciates Mega Gallade's ability to remove Dark- and Steel-types like Ting-Lu, Alolan Muk, Hisuian Goodra, and Ferrothorn and special walls like Blissey and Articuno. In return, Deoxys-S can eliminate Flying-types like Tornadus-T, Mega Aerodactyl, and Zapdos. Tapu Lele also threatens Dark-types like Mega Sableye and can set up Psychic Terrain, which boosts the power of Deoxys-S's Expanding Force and protects it from getting revenge killed by priority moves like Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak and Cinderace's Sucker Punch. Victini can deal with Steel- and Bug-types like Gholdengo and Scizor. Jirachi can set Stealth Rock and provide safe entry to Deoxys-S with U-turn. Choice Scarf Iron Boulder can take on opposing Choice Scarf users like Meowscarada, Greninja, and Blacephalon.

Specially Defensive (Water).description: Empoleon is one of Water's best options for role compression thanks to its wide array of utility options. Furthermore, its great special bulk coupled with a great defensive typing allows it to easily shrug off hits from some of the biggest threats to Water teams such as Tapu Lele and Kyurem. Defog removes entry hazards, allowing its teammates to switch in more safely, and it also removes opponents' dual screens to ease the Fairy matchup. Alternatively, Empoleon can run Stealth Rock to wear down foes over time to aid its offensive partners. Flash Cannon targets Fairy-types such as Mega Diancie and Tapu Lele. Knock Off targets Ghost- and Psychic-types like Hisuian Zoroark and Jirachi while removing items from foes that rely on them like Rotom-W and Corviknight. Alternatively, Flip Turn allows Empoleon to take advantage of its low Speed by acting as a slow pivot to bring its teammates in safely. Pelipper pairs well with Empoleon, as the two of them form a pivoting core, and it appreciates Empoleon taking on Tapu Lele and Kyurem. In return, Pelipper can run Defog so that Empoleon can choose to run Stealth Rock instead. Rain-boosted sweepers like Mega Swampert and Barraskewda appreciate Empoleon taking on Kyurem's Freeze-Dry and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, respectively, and in return, it provides an Electric immunity and can sweep under rain. Urshifu-R and Keldeo appreciate Empoleon setting up Stealth Rock and challenging Fairy-types; in return, the two of them challenge Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Hisuian Goodra. Choice Specs Greninja, with its great coverage, handles a myriad of threats to Empoleon such as non-Choice Scarf Iron Valiant, Great Tusk, and the Landorus formes, and it appreciates Defog and Stealth Rock support in return. Choice Scarf Hisuian Samurott can stack Spikes with Ceaseless Edge, and it takes on Ghost- and Psychic-types if Empoleon forgoes Knock Off. Ogerpon-W's Ground-resistant typing allows it to deal with the likes of the Landorus formes, Great Tusk, and Mamoswine in the Ground matchup.

Physically Defensive (Normal).description: As a switch-in to Fighting-types that compresses utility to support its team, Staraptor is a common part of defensive cores in Normal teams. Brave Bird lets Staraptor apply offensive pressure on Fighting-types such as Breloom and Mega Lopunny. Close Combat complements its coverage to hit Flying-resistant foes including Excadrill, Heatran, and Empoleon, discouraging the latter two from keeping Stealth Rock on it; alternatively, U-turn provides utility to more safely bring in allies such as Ditto, Hisuian Zoroark, and Mega Lopunny. The given EV spread lets it outspeed Adamant Tapu Bulu, with the rest being invested in physical bulk to ease handling foes including Mega Scizor, Dragonite, and Mega Pinsir. Chansey and Blissey's high special bulk lets them comfortably check a wide variety of special attackers that Staraptor can't handle such as Zapdos, Nihilego, and Nidoking, making a good defensive core that includes Ditto benefiting from the safe entry provided by Staraptor to minimize their potential passivity against setup sweepers. Mega Lopunny and Ursaluna can act as offensive pressure for opposing Rock-types, which Staraptor can't properly handle. Hisuian Zoroark benefits from Staraptor's entry hazard control to better bluff as another ally with Illusion, with Staraptor supporting it by checking Fighting-types in return.

Specially Defensive (Water).description: Gastrodon makes for a great Electric-immune teammate for Water teams thanks to its great utility options, special bulk, and defensive typing, which allows for Gastrodon to take on Choice Specs Zapdos. Clear Smog allows Gastrodon to negate setup attempts from sweepers such as Dragonite, Kommo-o, and Tapu Fini, while Ice Beam provides coverage against Dragon-types such as Dragonite and Hydreigon. Earthquake deals with Steel-types such as Hisuian Goodra and Gholdengo, whereas Toxic can be run to put switch-ins like Mantine and Rotom-W on a timer. Sticky Hold prevents Gastrodon from obtaining an unwanted Choice item from Hisuian Zoroark and Blacephalon by Trick. Toxapex forms a great defensive core with Gastrodon, as it is able to handle Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu, Ogerpon-W, and Meowscarada and stack entry hazards with Toxic Spikes. Empoleon makes for another great defensive partner, as not only can it set up Stealth Rock, but it also walls and takes on the likes of Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales. Ogerpon-W appreciates Gastrodon taking on Poison-types such as Sneasler and Alolan Muk, and in return, it aids in the Water mirror matchup, taking on the likes of Urshifu-R and Mega Swampert. Wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Greninja and Choice Band Urshifu-R appreciate Gastrodon placing Spikes and inflicting poison on foes so that they can more easily wallbreak against foes like Alolan Muk and Porygon2, respectively.

Physically Defensive (Ground).description: Gastrodon is a mainstay on Ground teams due to its vast utility options, great bulk along with reliable recovery, and a stellar ability in Storm Drain, checking a myriad of Water-types like Mega Swampert, Barraskewda, and Keldeo. Scald threatens physical attackers such as Dragonite, Mega Lopunny, and Mimikyu with a burn. Thanks to Gastrodon's bulk, it is able to stack multiple layers of Spikes to wear down opposing teams. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be used, freeing a moveslot from a teammate such as Garchomp or Hippowdon. Toxic puts troublesome walls such as Mantine, Ting-Lu, and Araquanid on a timer. Earthquake may be used alongside a Relaxed nature to break Calm Mind Keldeo's Substitute. All of Gastrodon's teammates appreciate its ability to switch into Water-type attacks. Unaware Clodsire checks Grass-types such as Meowscarada and Tapu Bulu as well as setup sweepers Gastrodon can't beat like Volcarona and Galarian Moltres. Iron Treads removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin so Gastrodon can better perform its defensive duties. Wallbreakers like Landorus and Great Tusk appreciate Gastrodon's entry hazard support so that they can net more damage. Mamoswine acts as a secondary Ice-type switch-in that checks the likes of SubRoost Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales, relieving pressure off of Gastrodon.

All-Out Attacker.description: Mega Lopunny is the best Mega Evolution available for Normal teams due to its blistering Speed tier, great offensive prowess, and unique ability in Scrappy. Fake Out lets Mega Lopunny serve as an exceptional revenge killer, dealing with worn down foes like Meowscarada, Barraskewda, and Alolan Raichu. It also puts Pokemon like Keldeo, Cinderace, and Tapu Koko in range of its other attacks safely. With Scrappy, Close Combat notably lets Mega Lopunny take on threats like Mega Sableye, Aegislash, and Gholdengo, threatening the defensive cores of Dark and Steel teams. U-turn enables Mega Lopunny to work as a potent offensive pivot, escaping unfavorable situations against walls like Slowbro and Mega Venusaur while keeping momentum. Triple Axel threatens common switch-ins such as Gliscor and Mandibuzz, while Return is Mega Lopunny's hardest-hitting move against most Psychic- and Fairy-types, such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Blissey is a great teammate, taking on the likes of Volcarona and Zapdos thanks to its bulk while offering support in the form of Stealth Rock, Toxic, and Teleport. Staraptor switches into Fighting-type attacks from Pokemon like Great Tusk, Buzzwole, and Tapu Bulu, and its access to Defog and U-turn also prolongs Mega Lopunny's longevity and lets it switch in unscathed. Special attackers like Hisuian Zoroark and Porygon-Z are able to break past physical walls Mega Lopunny can't, like Skeledirge, Corviknight, and Slowbro. Hisuian Zoroark also prevents Fighting-types from spamming their STAB moves aimed at Mega Lopunny.

Wallbreaker (Normal).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Swords Dance (Dragon).description: Garchomp is an incredible wallbreaker and setup sweeper for Dragon teams because of its high Attack stat and access to Swords Dance and Scale Shot. Earthquake threatens Steel- and Poison-types like Gholdengo, Hisuian Goodra, Alolan Muk, and Toxapex. At +2, Fire Fang OKHOes Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor; when boosted by Firium Z, it can also OHKO Skarmory, Corviknight, and Celesteela after Stealth Rock damage. Stone Edge targets Flying-types like Tornadus-T, Mega Aerodactyl, and Galarian Moltres and, in tandem with Rockium Z, allows Garchomp to OHKO Rotom-W at +2 after Stealth Rock damage. Loaded Dice is another option that synergizes with Scale Shot, providing a reliable STAB move to threaten Dragon-types like Kyurem, Mega Latias, and opposing Garchomp. Archaludon and Hisuian Goodra are excellent partners for Garchomp thanks to their partial Steel typing and exceptional bulk aiding against Fairy-types. Archaludon handles Mimikyu, Mega Altaria, and other physical attackers like Weavile, Meowscarada, and Roaring Moon while also providing Stealth Rock support. Hisuian Goodra takes on Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and other special attackers like Kyurem and Greninja. Kyurem can break through bulky Ground- and Flying-types like Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Mandibuzz. Teammates like Mega Altaria, Mega Latias, and Latios form formidable wallbreaking cores with Garchomp for their ability to threaten Fighting and Dragon teams. Additionally, Latios and Mega Latias can also wear down or eliminate Pokemon like Mega Venusaur, Skarmory, and Slowbro. In return, Garchomp can eliminate Steel- and Poison-types like Mega Scizor and Toxapex for Mega Altaria and Alolan Muk and Heatran for Mega Latias and Latios. Choice Scarf Roaring Moon can take on faster threats like Choice Scarf Latias and Enamorus, which Garchomp is unable to outspeed even at +1.

Defensive Hazard Setter (Dragon).description: Garchomp offers excellent utility as an entry hazard setter on Dragon teams due to its bulk, access to Spikes and Stealth Rock, and the ability to phaze opponents out via Dragon Tail. Earthquake allows Garchomp to threaten Steel- and Fire-types like Gholdengo, Hisuian Goodra, and Mega Charizard X. Dragon Tail phazes out setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Mega Latias, and Galarian Moltres, dealing a decent amount of chip damage; Roar may be used instead to force Fairy-types out. Fire Blast threatens Steel-types like Mega Scizor and Corviknight. Alternatively, a combination of Spikes and Stealth Rock in conjunction with Dragon Tail or Roar enable Garchomp to cause an incredible buildup of damage. Toxic may be used instead, as it puts opposing walls such as Ting-Lu, Staraptor, and Mandibuzz on a timer. Rocky Helmet in conjunction with Rough Skin provides even more chip damage on top of the entry hazards, heavily damaging foes with multi-hit moves such as Urshifu-R, Meowscarada, and Weavile while also punishing U-turn and Flip Turn from Sneasler and Barraskweda, respectively. The given EV spread permits Garchomp to outpace Pokemon with a base Speed of 100 like Mega Charizard X, Jirachi, and Volcarona while maintaining maximum defensive bulk. Kyurem capatalizes greatly on Garchomp's hazards, appreciating special walls such as Toxapex, Hisuian Goodra, and Alolan Muk being worn down. In return, Kyurem removes Flying-types like Landorus-T, Zapdos, and Mandibuzz and greatly weakens Mega Sableye, preventing it from repeatedly switching in to bounce back hazards being set by Garchomp. Hisuian Goodra provides a Fairy- and Ice-type neutrality, combating foes such as Tapu Koko, Alolan Ninetales, and, notably, Mega Diancie, which also hinders Garchomp's ability to stack hazards. Mega Altaria offers a much-valued immunity to Dragon-type moves, threatening Roaring Moon, Walking Wake, Kommo-o, and Latios while also cherishing Garchomp's hazards and ability to check Poison- and Steel-types like Toxapex, Gholdengo, and Iron Treads. Mega Latias is incredibly threatening in the Flying matchup due to its BoltBeam coverage, though it struggles against Celesteela, while also easily sweeping teams lacking Galarian Moltres via Stored Power and Calm Mind. Roaring Moon is a versatile teammate capable of handling multiple roles; a Choice Scarf set allows it to threaten Fairy-types such as Mega Diancie, Alolan Ninetales, and Tapu Lele via Iron Head, while Dragon Dance sets can overpower physically defensive Pokemon like Rotom-W, Slowbro, and Celesteela. Kommo-o is a great setup sweeper that removes pesky walls such as Porygon2 and Mega Scizor and is a massive threat to opposing Dragon teams. Both Roaring Moon and Kommo-o value Garchomp's entry hazards, with the latter also appreciating the removal of Clodsire. Choice Scarf Latias and Latios are excellent speed control options due to their ability to force switches in the Dragon matchup, luring out Hisuian Goodra for Garchomp. Choice Scarf Archaludon can catch Fairy- and Ice-types like Iron Valiant, Alolan Ninetales, and Kyurem off-guard while also being a secondary speed control option in a pinch in the Dragon mirror matchups.

Offensive Entry Hazard Setter (Dragon).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Swords Dance (Ground).description: Mega Garchomp's sky-high Attack and oppressive STAB moves make it a dangerous wallbreaker that can tear through defensive Pokemon like Mega Venusaur and Mega Sableye. Scale Shot gives Mega Garchomp the opportunity to boost its mediocre Speed and outrun would-be revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny and Choice Specs Greninja while obliterating opposing Dragon-types like Latios and Dragonite. Fire Fang targets Pokemon like Corviknight and Celesteela that wall Garchomp's STAB combination and can also OHKO Ferrothorn after a Swords Dance. It should also be noted that Garchomp can benefit from not Mega Evolving immediately, since the base forme's higher Speed lets it outrun threats like Kyurem, Urshifu-R, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele after a Scale Shot. With the chip damage from the Stealth Rock and sand that Hippowdon sets up, Mega Garchomp, after a Swords Dance boost, can use a Sand Force-enhanced Earthquake to take out neutral targets like Mega Venusaur and Mega Scizor. Excadrill provides speed control with Sand Rush and removes Ice- and Fairy types like Enamorus and Weavile, clearing the way for Mega Garchomp to remove walls like Slowbro and Celesteela that check Excadrill. Landorus is another good partner because it complements Mega Garchomp's physical strength with its powerful special attacks, which let it remove threats like Kyurem and Tapu Bulu with Focus Blast and Sludge Wave. Both Landorus formes also crucially provide Gravity, allowing Garchomp to temporarily ignore Ground immunities and fire off its deadly Earthquakes. Mamoswine threatens weakened Flying- and Dragon-types like Choice Scarf Enamorus and Latios with Ice Shard while being able to switch into Ice-type attacks directed at Garchomp, as it resists them due to Thick Fat. Finally, Clodsire provides Garchomp with a reliable Fairy resistance and Water-immune partner that packs Haze for setup sweepers like Volcarona and Kommo-o.

Swords Dance (Dark).description: Swords Dance Weavile makes for a great cleaner against types like Flying, Ground, and Dragon, as it deals with nuisances like Celesteela, Landorus, and Mega Altaria. Icium Z-boosted Icicle Crash lets Weavile break through and OHKO defensive walls like Celesteela, Gastrodon, and Ferrothorn after minimal chip damage at +2 and immediately remove Mega Diancie and bulkier variants of Mega Altaria. Although it is less consistent than Icicle Crash, Triple Axel provides Weavile with much higher wallbreaking power and the ability to immediately remove Ogerpon-C at the cost of making it vulnerable to contact damage from Skarmory and Ferrothorn and checked more easily by Archaludon. However, this lets Weavile use Heavy-Duty Boots instead of Icium Z due to Triple Axel's higher damage ceiling than Icicle Crash. Knock Off removes key items from switch-ins like Rotom-W, Archaludon, and Celesteela, making them easier for Weavile to overwhelm later. Ice Shard picks off faster threats like Mega Aerodactyl and Choice Scarf users like Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Enamorus. Ting-Lu provides entry hazard support, which helps Weavile gain the appropriate thresholds for OHKOing defensive walls like Celesteela, and it also deals with special attackers like Volcarona, Tapu Lele, and Tapu Koko. Nasty Plot Hydreigon and Galarian Moltres form a potent wallbreaking core with Weavile, with the former dealing with Slowbro, Archaludon, and Toxapex and the latter handling faster threats like Latios and Enamorus. Weavile also fits on hyper offense teams, with teammates like Grimmsnarl providing dual screens support to give it more room to set up and Dragon Dance Mega Tyranitar battering down opposing teams for it to clean up later. If slotted in on balance teams, Weavile greatly appreciates Mega Sableye and Mandibuzz keeping entry hazards off the field and taking on Fighting-types like Sneasler. Mandibuzz also checks physical setup sweepers like Mega Scizor with Foul Play and pivots Weavile in with U-turn.

Choice Scarf (Ice).description: Choice Scarf Weavile is an excellent revenge killer on Ice teams because of its powerful STAB combination, access to Pursuit, and an incredible Speed stat that allows it to outspeed threats like Mega Aerodactyl, Mega Lopunny, and Choice Scarf users like Iron Boulder, Blacephalon, and Tapu Lele. Pursuit allows Weavile to trap and eliminate foes like Blacephalon and Iron Boulder that threaten Ice teams, while Punishment threatens Z-Celebrate Victini and Z-Happy Hour users like Jirachi and Hisuian Zoroark. Knock Off hinders defensive switch-ins like Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Toxapex by removing their Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots. Low Kick targets foes like Heatran, Iron Treads, and Mega Tyranitar. Kyurem, Alolan Ninetales, and Arctozolt are excellent partners for their ability to break through bulky Water-types like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Swampert, which Weavile struggles against. Arctozolt, Galarian Darmanitan, Cetitan, and Kyurem can also wear down or eliminate Steel-types like Skarmory, Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Archaludon, allowing Weavile to clean up late-game. Cloyster and Piloswine set entry hazards, which, in conjunction with Weavile's Knock Off removing Heavy-Duty Boots, can wear down bulky foes. Additionally, Cloyster also provides entry hazard removal with Rapid Spin, increasing Weavile's survivability, while Piloswine can check Fire-types like Volcarona and Heatran.

Air Balloon (Electric).description: Magnezone draws in troublesome Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Excadrill, and Klefki to convert them to scrap metal while serving as a reliable switch-in to Moonblast from Tapu Lele and Enamorus for Electric teams. Hidden Power Fire is essential for dealing as much damage as possible before Klefki or Excadrill set too many entry hazards or break Magnezone after enough attacks. Flash Cannon obliterates Fairy-types such as Mega Diancie and Tapu Lele. Substitute allows Magnezone to block Leech Seed from Ferrothorn and Celesteela, and it also provides an opportunity to secure a second OHKO against Fairy teams after trapping and eliminating Klefki. Volt Switch helps Magnezone to maintain momentum and chip away at Corviknight before it inevitably uses U-turn turns, while Thunderbolt 2HKOes Celesteela. The first EV spread lets Magnezone survive two Moonblasts from Choice Specs Tapu Lele while still being able to outspeed Skarmory. Maximum Special Attack and Speed can be considered, as this lets Magnezone outspeed and OHKO most variants of Mega Scizor before getting OHKOed by it. As Magnezone is able to deal with Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Excadrill, which take Electric-type attacks with ease, Rising Voltage users like Regieleki and Alolan Raichu greatly benefit from having Magnezone as a teammate. In return, these teammates provide speed control, dealing with Iron Valiant, Volcarona, and Ogerpon-W. Tapu Koko benefits from Celesteela getting removed, as this means it's able to use Hidden Power Ice more freely against Flying teams, and it deals with Kommo-o and Mega Gallade. Zapdos and Rotom-W are great Ground-immune teammates to fall back on after Magnezone's Air Balloon is popped, and Rotom-W appreciates the removal of Mold Breaker Excadrill, which otherwise threatens it. Raging Bolt becomes even scarier once Steel-types are removed by Magnezone, allowing it to spam Draco Meteor with impunity. Iron Hands and Zeraora appreciate Magnezone removing Klefki in the Fairy matchup, preventing it from setting its dual screens, and trapping Protect scouters like Ferrothorn in Steel teams, which allows them to play more aggressively against these teams. Magnezone also is a slow pivot that brings in these wallbreakers, which is greatly appreciated by most Electric-types.

Stallbreaker (Flying).description: Gliscor is a great addition to Flying teams, as its part-Ground typing allows it to be a useful asset in the Electric and Rock matchups, threatening the likes of Magnezone, Zeraora, and Hisuian Arcanine. Knock Off removes important items such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Volcarona, Tornadus-T, and Dragonite and Leftovers from Corviknight. Taunt shuts down entry hazard attempts as well as attempts to remove its teammates' hazards with Defog. Roost grants Gliscor a form of longevity on top of Poison Heal. 244 HP and 20 Defense EVs allow it to survive a V-create from Choice Band Victini, while 8 Speed EVs outspeed Modest Raging Bolt. Corviknight and Mantine remove hazards with Defog so Gliscor can switch in more safely. Additionally, Corviknight provides slow pivoting and threatens Fairy-types like Tapu Lele and Mega Diancie, while Mantine handles Water-types like Barraskewda and Mega Swampert. Thundurus-T takes pressure off Gliscor by providing an additional Electric immunity; it also threatens Water- and Flying-types such as Urshifu-R, Swampert, Mantine, and Corviknight with its coverage. It appreciates Gliscor removing Clodsire and blocking entry hazard setup with Taunt. Late-game sweepers such as Mega Charizard Y and Galarian Moltres appreciate Gliscor's stallbreaking against Toxapex, Clodsire, and Heatran so they can start their own sweep. In return, Mega Charizard Y handles Ferrothorn, Gastrodon, and Alolan Ninetales, while Galarian Moltres handles Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Gholdengo, Ceruledge, and Slowbro.

Choice Band (Ground).description: Mamoswine is an incredible Choice Band user for Ground-type teams thanks to its raw power and excellent STAB coverage, making it a force to be reckoned with. Ice Shard helps it pick off faster Pokemon that can threaten it, such as Thundurus-T, Enamorus, and Latias. Knock Off heavily weakens Pokemon reliant on their items, such as Corviknight, Porygon2, and Celesteela, making them much easier for Mamoswine to take advantage of later on. Alternatively, Superpower is Mamoswine’s best option for beating bulky Pokemon such as Blissey, Ferrothorn, and Rotom-W. Landorus is an outstanding teammate for Mamoswine to have, as it can threaten physical walls Mamoswine would rather not face, such as Mega Venusaur, Tapu Fini, and Slowbro, and help it beat Ground-immune Pokemon such as Skarmory and Rotom-W with Gravity. Scale Shot Mega Garchomp and Sand Rush Excadrill appreciate Mamoswine wearing down bulky Pokemon such as Celesteela and Gliscor for them to clean up late-game. Ting-Lu and Hippowdon help Mamoswine do its job more effectively by setting up entry hazards, allowing it to net more KOs. They also can rack up chip damage with Whirlwind, and Hippowdon sets sand for further residual damage. Clodsire and Gastrodon can safely switch into Water-type moves that threaten Mamoswine, and they can set hazards to help its wallbreaking. Clodsire, in particular, is able to switch into Grass-type attacks from the likes of Choice Scarf Meowscarada, Ogerpon-W, and Brambleghast, and it can inflict status and set Toxic Spikes up, limiting the longevity of stall Pokemon such as Slowbro, Ting-Lu, and Blissey. Gastrodon is an excellent Water Absorb user that can ease up Water matchups for Mamoswine, as it can safely wall Water-type Pokemon such as Choice Specs Walking Wake, Dondozo, and Mega Swampert with the proper moveset to take advantage of later on.

Z-Conversion.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Swords Dance (Fighting).description: For Fighting teams, Mega Gallade is one of the best choices, courtesy of its incredible offensive power, typing, and Speed, being the best counter to Fighting's biggest roadblock, Toxapex. Swords Dance increases Mega Gallade's power to the maximum, letting it freely overpower the likes of Mandibuzz and Celesteela. Zen Headbutt beautifully complements a Fighting-type STAB move, as it lets Mega Gallade easily break through any opposing Poison-types that may be annoying walls such as Mega Venusaur, Toxapex, and Clodsire. Knock Off is another tool in Mega Gallade's arsenal, which lets it take care of Psychic- and Ghost-types—such as Gholdengo, Slowbro, and Aegislash—and wears down Celesteela into range of Close Combat finishing it off. Triple Axel is another option to easily take care of Flying-types such as Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Enamorus. Shadow Sneak can also be considered to pick off faster weakened threats such as Gengar, Choice Scarf Blacephalon, and Mega Alakazam. With all its benefits, Mega Gallade has a few checks in Skeledirge and defensive Gholdengo; hence, offensive Great Tusk and Urshifu-R are great partners in helping take these down. Defensive Great Tusk also helps in setting and removing entry hazards, which is appreciated by Mega Gallade. Mega Gallade is also easily revenge killed by faster offensive threats such as Tornadus-T and Choice Scarf Blacephalon, so Assault Vest Iron Hands is a good check to stop these in their tracks and deal good damage back while also being able to pivot in Mega Gallade with Volt Switch. Breloom and Lilligant-H also helps significantly in the Water matchup against the likes of Mega Swampert and Barraskewda; they can also put opposing foes to sleep to make Gallade's setup easier. Choice Scarf Sneasler helps in the Fairy matchup against the likes of Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Tapu Koko while also being able to set and absorb Toxic Spikes and can U-Turn to pivot in Mega Gallade safely. Iron Valiant is also an amazing partner in the form of a specially offensive threat, complementing Mega Gallade, as it can easily take care of Mega Sableye. Choice Scarf Iron Valiant also outspeeds Mega Swampert under rain and Regieleki under Electric Terrain, making it a great revenge killer if Mega Gallade gets knocked out.

Swords Dance (Psychic).description: Mega Gallade is a potent wallbreaker on Psychic teams thanks to its greatly appreciated Dark neutrality and good coverage in Knock Off and Triple Axel. Swords Dance allows Mega Gallade to grab a boost on a forced switch and potentially win the game with its high base Speed and astronomical Attack after one boost. Knock Off is crucial to hit opposing Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Slowbro and Gholdengo that would otherwise wall this set, and its item removal is always handy in breaking defensive teams reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots down with Stealth Rock damage and removing key items from Celesteela and Toxapex. Finally, Zen Headbutt does massive work against Poison teams after a single Swords Dance and deals high amounts of damage to Fighting-resistant Pokemon such as Buzzwole and Toxapex. Triple Axel is another alternative, allowing Mega Gallade to hit Flying- and Dragon-types such as Landorus-T and Garchomp. Shadow Sneak can allow Mega Gallade to outspeed and take out Ghost-types such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Choice Scarf Blacephalon that could otherwise beat it. Tapu Lele forms a wallbreaking core with Mega Gallade, as they both threaten common checks to each other. Tapu Lele beats Mega Sableye with Moonblast, while Mega Gallade crushes Steel-types such as Heatran and Celesteela that trouble Tapu Lele with Close Combat. Jirachi can take Fairy-type attacks such as Tapu Lele's Moonblast aimed for Mega Gallade, as well as paralyze threats and beat them down with Thunder Wave and Serene Grace-boosted Iron Head, letting Mega Gallade break through them with a timely paralysis. Finally, Jirachi provides Stealth Rock support and a safe pivot in with U-turn. Victini provides speed control with Choice Scarf and defeats Steel-types such as Choice Scarf Gholdengo that Mega Gallade is forced out by while appreciating Mega Gallade's ability to pound Heatran to dust. Deoxys-S provides entry hazard and dual screens support, which Mega Gallade can take advantage of with Knock Off and Swords Dance to break through bulkier teams. Slowbro provides crucial momentum with Teleport while also being able to annoy teams with Scald burns and Future Sight and switch in repeatedly through Regenerator. Celebi can break through troubling physical walls such as Hippowdon and Dondozo that Mega Gallade struggles to make progress against. Finally, Choice Scarf Latias can both remove entry hazards with Defog and use Healing Wish to give Mega Gallade a second chance to break through the opposing team.

Bulky Pivot (Electric).description: With its access to Levitate, Rotom-W is nearly mandatory on all Electric teams. Its Ground immunity and Water-type resistance make Pokemon like Mega Swampert unable to bother it; it also has access to Hydro Pump to hit annoying Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Hippowdon. Rotom-W is also a really good blanket check to Ice- and Fire-types like Mamoswine, Victini, and Galarian Darmanitan. Volt Switch provides great momentum, which is needed in hyper offense teams. In addition to providing momentum, Rotom-W has access to Will-O-Wisp and Toxic, crippling foes such as Mega Garchomp and Mimikyu with Will-O-Wisp, while Toxic punishes switch-ins such as Gastrodon and Kyurem. Defog lets Rotom-W compress roles, freeing up Zapdos to run Choice Specs, while Rotom-W prevents hazards from hurting teammates. Pain Split is another option, as it massively improves Rotom-W's longevity; however, this requires Zapdos to run Defog. The 44 invested Speed EVs ensure Rotom-W outspeeds Jolly Azumarill so that it can punish Azumarill for setting up Belly Drum with Will-O-Wisp or Volt Switch. Zapdos covers Rotom-W's weakness to Grass-types with access to Hurricane and Heat Wave, being able to OHKO the likes of Mega Venusaur and Ferrothorn, respectively, while also being immune to Mold Breaker Excadrill's Earthquake. Regieleki can be used as a Rapid Spinner, removing pressure from Rotom-W to function as the only hazard removal while also luring in Ground-types that Rotom-W can punish such as Iron Treads or Great Tusk. With access to Taunt and having an amazing Speed tier, Zeraora can prevent hazards from coming up and allow Rotom-W to switch in freely and get off a strong Hydro Pump or gain a lot of momentum and Volt Switch into one of its offensive teammates. Zeraora also pressures Hydreigon and Gholdengo, which can use Rotom-W as setup fodder. Iron Hands provides the coverage and bulk against Pokemon like Dragon Dance Dragonite, Volcarona, and SubRoost Kyurem that Rotom-W can't deal with while also putting a lot of pressure on Normal teams, as Rotom-W can Volt Switch against Blissey into Iron Hands and force Blissey to tank a hit or switch out. Alolan Raichu gives Rotom-W's slow Volt Switch a lot of value as it is strong but frail, being able to deal with Ice-types like Baxcalibut with Focus Blast and Poison-types like Mega Venusaur and Clodsire with Psyshock. Magnezone provides a valuable Poison immunity while also checking other threats like Tapu Lele, Meowscarada, and Alolan Ninetales.

Stallbreaker (Fire).description: Heatran is a great addition to Fire teams, serving as a stallbreaker with its access to Magma Storm and Taunt, and with Air Balloon, it answers Mega Diancie, Excadrill, and the Landorus formes while also providing excellent utility in Stealth Rock and Flame Body. Magma Storm is a powerful trapping tool against walls like Toxapex, Hippowdon, and Clodsire. Earth Power targets Fire- and Poison-types like opposing Heatran and Toxapex, which are immune to or resist Magma Storm. Flash Cannon allows Heatran to OHKO Fairy-types like Mega Diancie and Enamorus, which threaten Fire teams. On the other hand, Hidden Power Ice threatens Ground-types like Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Garchomp. With Taunt, Heatran can stop recovery for foes like Toxapex and Clodsire while also denying entry hazards from these foes as well as others like Gliscor. Alternatively, Stealth Rock allows it to support itself and its teammates like Ceruledge and Volcarona by wearing down the opposing team. Air Balloon provides Heatran with a Ground immunity, allowing it to deal with the aforementioned threats safely as long as its Air Balloon is intact. Torkoal and Ninetales serve as sun setters, boosting the power of Heatran's Magma Storm and softening Water-type moves. Torkoal also provides entry hazard removal with Rapid Spin and acts as an alternate Stealth Rock setter. Dragon Dance Mega Charizard X handles Dragon-types like Kyurem and Hydreigon. In return, Heatran can sponge attacks from Choice Scarf Latias. Mega Charizard Y is another sun setter that also provides a Ground immunity in case Heatran's Air Balloon has already been popped and offensively threatens Sand Rush Excadrill and Mega Swampert, which pose an immense threat to Fire teams, by resetting the weather and threatening them back with Fire Blast and Solar Beam, respectively. Z-Celebrate Victini deals with Fighting-types like Great Tusk and Iron Hands. Teammates like Volcarona, Iron Moth, and Blacephalon appreciate Heatran's ability to trap and eliminate foes like Toxapex and Clodsire. Volcarona can threaten Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Hydreigon that pose problems for Heatran. Choice Scarf Iron Moth and Blacephalon serve as revenge killers; Iron Moth deals with Kommo-o, while Blacephalon threatens Mega Gallade and can eliminate the Landorus formes for Heatran if running Hidden Power Ice, allowing Heatran to run a different move. Focus Sash Ceruledge can use its Fighting immunity to switch into Fighting-types like Iron Valiant, and Sneasler, threatening them back with its STAB moves. It also serves as a wallbreaker, removing special walls like Blissey and Swampert and Rock-types like Mega Tyranitar and Iron Boulder. In return, Heatran can deny entry hazards with Taunt to keep Ceruledge's Focus Sash intact, allowing it to reliably take on the aforementioned foes. Volcanion boasts a Water immunity, which allows it switch in against Water-type attacks from Choice Specs Greninja, Azumarill, and Choice Band Barraskewda; it can also eliminate bulky Ground-types like Hippowdon and Ting-Lu with Steam Eruption, which can potentially burn other foes.

Specially Defensive (Steel).description: Heatran is a mainstay on Steel teams due to its ability, Flash Fire, letting it switch into threats like Blacephalon, Victini, and Iron Moth. Lava Plume makes Heatran annoying to switch into thanks to its burn chance, while Magma Storm softens walls like Toxapex and Rotom-W by trapping them. Earth Power threatens Poison- and Fire-types and makes Heatran an important asset against opposing Steel teams by hitting opposing Heatran. Roar lets Heatran phaze the likes of Nasty Plot Hydreigon and Z-Celebrate Victini and synergizes well with Stealth Rock to deal extra damage. Alternatively, Toxic cripples walls like Mantine and Rotom-W, as well as Pokemon that fancy switching into Heatran such as Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y. Substitute pairs well with Toxic and allows Heatran to be massively annoying against types like Steel, Electric, and Psychic by capitalizing on the many switches it forces in these matchups. Thanks to their typing and bulk, Corviknight and Celesteela are excellent teammates to check Ground- and Fighting-types like Mamoswine and Great Tusk for Heatran. Setup sweepers like Mega Scizor and Z-Happy Hour Jirachi appreciate Heatran wearing down teams with burn and Toxic. Iron Treads removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin and deals with Mega Charizard Y, Zeraora, and Cinderace with its Choice Scarf set. Ferrothorn checks Water-types like Mega Swampert and Urshifu-R and aids Heatran with Spikes and Leech Seed.

Choice Band (Psychic).description: Victini is a great wallbreaker on Psychic teams due to its well-rounded coverage and signature move in V-create, easing the matchup against Steel, Grass, and Ice teams. Bolt Strike threatens bulky Water-types such as Toxapex, Slowbro, and Tapu Fini that resist V-create. U-turn preserves Psychic's momentum and allows Victini to switch out of Pokemon that wall it like Dragonite and Mega Altaria. Trick cripples common switch-ins such as Storm Drain Gastrodon, Toxapex, and Skeledirge, while Brick Break lets Victini further threaten Steel and Dark teams by hitting Heatran and Mega Tyranitar hard. Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is an excellent teammate due to its ability to check Dark- and Dragon-types like Weavile, Kommo-o, and Hydreigon. It also sets up Psychic Terrain, protecting Victini from priority moves from the likes of Mimikyu and Azumarill. Jirachi and Celebi aid in Victini's wallbreaking by setting up Stealth Rock and replenishing its HP with Healing Wish. Furthermore, they form a pivot core with Victini that deals sizable chip damage while keeping momentum. Latias also provides Healing Wish support and removes entry hazards with Defog to preserve Victini's longevity. Mega Gallade and Victini can each weaken certain physical walls for the other to dispose of such as Ting-Lu and Skeledirge. Deoxys-S breaks through roadblocks like Toxapex, Garchomp, and Swampert and aids in cleaning weakened Flying and Water teams. Slowbro switches into most Water- and Ground-types that threaten Victini, like Urshifu-R and Excadrill, and it brings Victini into the field with Teleport.

Z-Celebrate (Fire).description: Victini is an excellent user of Z-Celebrate, which not only boosts its natural bulk, but also its amazing offensive potential. Stored Power in tandem with Z-Celebrate can easily shred through bulky Pokemon such as Toxapex and Gliscor. Focus Blast is a great form of coverage for Victini, as it can break down Dark-, Rock-, and Steel-types such as Tyranitar, Hisuian Arcanine, and Heatran; its low accuracy is also boosted by Victory Star. Alternatively, after a boost, Thunderbolt can threaten Water- and Flying-type Pokemon such as non-Choice Scarf Greninja, Pelipper, and Mega Charizard Y. Torkoal is an excellent teammate to pair with Victini, as not only does it provide sun to boost Victini's Searing Shot, notably giving it a favorable roll to take out Tapu Lele after a boost, but it also provides entry hazard removal in Rapid Spin. Torkoal can also set Stealth Rock of its own, which breaks Sturdy of foes like Skarmory and Ogerpon-C, allowing Victini to sweep. Cinderace can break through bulky Pokemon such as Blissey with itsLibero-boosted STAB High Jump Kick while also using Court Change to remove hazards for Victini. Rotom-H provides an immunity to Ground-types with Levitate and assists by setting up dual screens, letting Victini take advantage of them to set up; it also has a niche in being another hazard removal teammate with Defog. Volcarona's Bug typing and access to Quiver Dance and Bug Buzz can check threatening Dark-types such as Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Hydreigon. Mega Charizard X is a powerful wallbreak that, paired alongside Victini, can take out Dragon-type threats such as Dragonite after its Multiscale is worn down and Kyurem. Ceruledge is another offensive setup sweeper that can take out Ghost-type Pokemon like Blacephalon and a weakened Iron Boulder with Shadow Sneak.

Heavy-Duty Boots (Psychic).description: Victini straps on its Heavy-Duty Boots to ignore entry hazards set by Steel, Fairy, and Flying teams, which limit its progress-making capabilities. Bolt Strike synergizes with V-create, targeting Water- and Flying-types like Toxapex and Gyarados. Substitute eases the Steel and Flying matchups by reducing the need for predictions and ensuring that Victini can deal damage to Heatran or Gliscor by scaring out Ferrothorn or Corviknight. Toxic puts walls like Porygon2 and Slowbro on a timer. Encore prevents slower setup users like Swords Dance Iron Hands and Nasty Plot Hydreigon from gaining momentum while also locking defensive foes like Corviknight and Gliscor into unfavorable moves. Power-Up Punch is effective in conjunction with Substitute, as it provides Victini with enough firepower to break through walls in subsequent turns, allowing it to OHKO Gliscor with V-create at +1 after Stealth Rock damage and 2HKO Slowbro and Heatran with Bolt Strike. If these extra wallbreaking capabilities are unnecessary, U-turn lets Victini pivot out of Heatran or Swampert. Victini finds it hard to break through dedicated physical walls like Hippowdon and Archaludon and Dragon-types like Dragonite, so teammates like Latios and Choice Specs Tapu Lele that deal with these are excellent teammates . Setup sweepers like Mega Gallade, Mega Latias, Iron Boulder, and Celebi can find use with Victini locking walls like Ferrothorn and Toxapex into unfavorable moves, and they also remove Landorus, Archaludon, Mega Swampert, and Ogerpon-W. Choice Scarf Iron Boulder provides speed control, hammering fast threats like Mega Lopunny, Choice Scarf Greninja, and Choice Scarf Roaring Moon. Slowbro and Galarian Slowking are decent walls that safely pivot Victini in; Slowbro also takes on scary Ground- and Water-types like Excadrill and Barraskewda, while Galarian Slowking is able to set Toxic Spikes and check Iron Valiant and Keldeo. Jirachi provides hazards and deals with Mega Diancie and Kyurem; in return, Victini deals with Gholdengo and Mega Scizor.

Choice Band (Ground).description: Boasting a powerful Attack stat and the ability Sand Rush, Excadrill is a powerful sweeper for sand teams. While sand is active, Excadrill outspeeds Choice Scarf Meowscarada, which otherwise poses a threat to Ground-type teams. Earthquake in tandem with Choice Band 2KHOes defensive switch-ins like Archaludon and Ferrothorn. Iron Head poses a threat to Fairy-types like Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Mega Diancie, while hitting Pokemon with Levitate such as Latios. Rock Slide helps to target Flying- and Bug-type threats like Zapdos and Volcarona. Poison Jab is excellent coverage that deals with Grass-types like Ogerpon-W and Tapu Bulu. X-Scissor can alternatively be used to check Psychic-type switch-ins like Slowbro while still being good against Ogerpon-W. Eject Button Hippowdon is a necessary teammate to pair with Excadrill due to its ability to set sand while also being an excellent defensive pivot that sets entry hazards. Landorus, with the help of Gravity, allows Excadrill to hit Pokemon with Levitate like Rotom-W, and it is also a great answer to defensive Steel- and Flying-types like Skarmory and Corviknight once Gravity is active. It also assists in dealing with Tapu Bulu and Slowbro, depending on which move Excadrill lacks. Mamoswine helps Excadrill by wallbreaking Flying-types that it naturally cannot deal with, like Gliscor, with its powerful Ice-type STAB moves. Clodsire, with the ability Water Absorb, turns into a great specially defensive wall, as it is immune to any incoming Water-type attacks while also being an excellent means of spreading status and setting up hazards with Poison Jab and Toxic Spikes, respectively. Alternatively, Sandy Shocks is another great Gravity setter for Excadrill that can naturally check Flying- and Water-types like Pelipper and Celesteela with its Electric-type STAB moves. Sandy Shocks is also a great answer to Mega Charizard Y, as Drought activates its Protosynthesis. Great Tusk, in conjunction with Excadrill, utilizes a Choice Scarf to remove Dark-types like Weavile and Ting-Lu with its powerful Fighting-type STAB moves.

Swords Dance (Ground).description: Having multiple ways to boost its Speed and holding a nearly unresisted STAB combination, Excadrill is a potent setup sweeper for Ground-type sand teams, as it can take advantage of forced switches by posing as its Choice Band set. Corkscrew Crash lets Excadrill overwhelm multiple checks, OHKOing Tornadus-T when unboosted; Sinistcha, Mega Latias, and Mega Sableye at +2; and Mega Venusaur at +2 after Stealth Rock damage. Rapid Spin lets Excadrill compress utility by removing entry hazards for its team while also raising its Speed; Rapid Spin is also a good move to finish foes off to make Excadrill more difficult to revenge kill. Excadrill appreciates Hippowdon, which is a sand setter required to easily enable Sand Rush. Excadrill can struggle against Water-types that are immune to Ground such as Rotom-W and Pelipper, so it appreciates Gastrodon and Clodsire as allies to pivot to; in turn they can support Excadrill by setting entry hazards or crippling the aforementioned foes with status. Flying-types such as Mega Charizard Y, Zapdos, and Skarmory can also be problematic for Excadrill to deal with, so checks such as Mega Garchomp and Mamoswine are appreciated.

Utility (Grass).description: Whimsicott is a unique and effective pivot option for Grass teams by virtue of its Prankster ability and many viable support moves. U-turn provides Whimsicott with a means to pivot into another teammate in order to maintain momentum. Alternatively, Knock Off can be used over U-turn to take advantage of Encore forcing switches by providing important item removal. The given EV spread makes Whimsicott as fast as possible while maximizing the damage of its Moonblast, letting it 2HKO Mega Sableye and Mandibuzz, and OHKO pokemon like Iron Valiant. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Whimsicott to switch in several times per match without being worn down by entry hazards. Ferrothorn is an excellent partner, since its Steel typing lets it wall Poison- and Steel-type attacks that threaten Whimsicott, and its entry hazards also pair well with Whimsicott's ability to force switches. Celebi is an excellent partner for Whimsicott thanks to its ability to threaten Poison and Steel teams that can make Whimsicott's opportunities to switch in very limited. Ogerpon-C benefits greatly from Whimsicott clearing away hazards so that it can make use of Sturdy to tank a hit it otherwise can't, and it appreciates Encore to help create setup opportunities. A Sunny Day set with Heat Rock can turn Whimsicott into a makeshift sun setter for teams that utilize Chlorophyll sweepers like Venusaur, Hisuian Lilligant, and Scovillain.

Victory Dance (Grass).description: With Close Combat and Victory Dance, Hisuian Lilligant is a powerful wallbreaker on Grass teams, covering the difficult Flying, Dragon, and Steel matchups. Close Combat nails bulky Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra and Heatran. Leaf Blade is a reliable secondary STAB move that can break Toxapex and offensive Gholdengo while also dealing with Gastrodon, Rotom-W, and Slowbro; however, Sleep Powder can be used instead to facilitate setting up with Victory Dance. Hustle-boosted Ice Spinner takes out Dragon-, Ground-, and Flying-types like Garchomp, Landorus, Dragonite, Mega Aerodactyl, and Zapdos after a Victory Dance. At +1, All Out-Pummeling can reliably KO tanks like Celesteela, Corviknight, and Iron Hands and, thanks to the Hustle boost, Fighting-resistant foes like Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y while ignoring the accuracy drop. Meowscarada is a perfect teammate that appreciates Hisuian Lilligant's removal of walls like Ferrothorn and Archaludon that switch into it. Meowscarada in return threatens Ghost- and Psychic-types like Gholdengo, Latios, and Latias, which Hisuian Lilligant can't touch. Mega Venusaur and Ferrothorn are defensive partners that deal with Fairy- and Poison-types like Tapu Lele and Sneasler while wearing down teams with Leech Seed and entry hazards, respectively. Ogerpon-C threatens Flying- and Fire-types like Moltres and Torkoal while benefiting from the removal of Steel-types. Whimsicott is a great support ally that removes hazards and can use Encore to give Lilligant more chances to set up. Brambleghast is another hazard removal option and spinblocker that can defend against Zapdos and Tornadus-T's Hurricane and Heat Wave with Wind Rider while providing crucial Spikes support.

Choice Scarf.description: Galarian Darmanitan easily applies offensive pressure thanks to the sheer damage output of its moves and Speed with the combo of Gorilla Tactics + Choice Scarf, allowing it to act as a potent revenge killer and wallbreaker for Ice teams. Flare Blitz provides coverage against Steel-types including Corviknight and Ferrothorn. Earthquake further complements Galarian Darmanitarian's moveset to provide nearly unresisted coverage alongside its STAB Icicle Crash, OHKOing Fire-types that resist its other moves such as Ceruledge and Heatran. U-turn allows Galarian Darmanitan to gain momentum on predicted switches and wears down checks over time. As Galarian Darmanitan can struggle with Water-types such as Toxapex, Slowbro, and Araquanid, Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales make for formidable partners, as they hit these foes super effectively with Freeze-Dry and can take advantage of their passivity to apply further pressure on the opposing team. Getting Choice locked into the wrong move often forces Galarian Darmanitan to switch out; therefore, Piloswine and Articuno act as defensive partners to resort to in such scenarios. Articuno and Cloyster can provide entry hazard control to mitigate Galarian Darmanitan's weakness to Stealth Rock, raising its longevity, with the former also providing pivoting to ease Galarian Darmanitan's entry into the field. Other offensive partners such as Weavile and Cetitan can complement Galarian Darmanitan in applying offensive pressure to overwhelm opposing walls and potentially sweep.

Z-Happy Hour (Ghost).description: With a Ghost immunity, Hisuian Zoroark covers a crucial weakness for its team and makes use of it alongside Illusion to bluff as any of its allies efficiently and gain opportunities to set up and sweep. Focus Blast is unresisted alongside Shadow Ball and hits Dark-types that could be difficult to answer otherwise such as Hydreigon and Mega Tyranitar. Hyper Voice provides a complementary STAB option that shines in neutral matchups, 2HKOing Mega Venusaur and Toxapex after a boost, but Flamethrower complements Focus Blast to hit Steel-types such as Corviknight and Scizor. Hisuian Zoroark's sole weakness to Dark can lure in checks that can threaten a good portion of its team such as Alolan Muk and Mandibuzz. Mega Sableye is a good partner to check them in turn, and it can also prevent entry hazards from being set on its side with Magic Bounce to increase Hisuian Zoroark's longevity and allow it to bluff with Illusion further. Mimikyu discourages Dark-type attacks thanks to its Fairy typing, giving a safe option for Hisuian Zoroark to bluff as with Illusion, and an intact Disguise also lures the opposing team to expect setup and either bring in a physical wall or use utility moves such as Taunt and Will-O-Wisp that don't hinder Hisuian Zoroark as much they would Mimikyu, easing setup. Hisuian Zoroark's Illusion in general can be used to bluff as other Pokemon to lure counterplay to them that it exploits; for example, as Gholdengo, it can discourage status moves by pretending to have Good as Gold, and as Sinistcha, it can revenge kill unsuspecting foes that would normally outspeed Sinistcha.

Z-Happy Hour (Normal).description: Hisuian Zoroark provides defensive utility relevant to its team by being immune to Fighting, allowing it to easily pose as any of its allies with Illusion to find setup opportunities and sweep. Focus Blast and Shadow Ball provide unresisted coverage, allowing Hisuian Zoroark to defeat checks such as Mega Tyranitar, Heatran, and Hydreigon. Flamethrower hits foes it wouldn't OHKO otherwise, even after a boost, such as Ferrothorn, Corviknight after minimal chip, and opposing Hisuian Zoroark. Flamethrower alongside Focus Blast considerably eases the Steel matchup for its team, but Hyper Voice is an alternative that deals the most damage in neutral matchups, OHKOing Tapu Koko and Tornadus-T at +1 after Stealth Rock. Hyper Voice can also be used to trigger Breakneck Blitz over Z-Happy Hour to allow Hisuian Zoroark to lure in and overwhelm foes such as Keldeo, Hisuian Lilligant, and Landorus in a pinch. As Hisuian Zoroark lures in Dark-types to check it, Mega Lopunny is a solid partner to keep momentum against such foes, especially as Hisuian Zoroark can bluff as Mega Lopunny more effectively than other teammates, as both hold an item that cannot be removed by Trick or Switcheroo. Mega Lopunny also pressures special walls that Hisuian Zoroark can otherwise struggle with, such as Mega Sableye, Blissey, and Alolan Muk. Entry hazard control by Staraptor is also valuable to ensure Hisuan Zoroark's bluffing capabilities and raise its longevity; Staraptor can also provide a slow pivot to let Hisuian Zoroark come in safely. Chansey and Blissey can set Stealth Rock to let Hisuian Zoroark more easily threaten a sweep and can support it by providing safe pivoting for it with Teleport. In particular, it is easier for Hisuian Zoroark to disguise as Chansey due to a shared vulnerability to entry hazards.

Sticky Web (Bug).description: Galvantula serves as an excellent Sticky Web lead, supporting its offensive team members with speed control. Thunder in conjunction with Compound Eyes gives Galvantula an offensive presence, takes on opposing hazard-setting leads, threatens paralysis, and dents Water- and Flying-types. Energy Ball threatens bulky Ground-types like Great Tusk, Hippowdon, Swampert, and Gastrodon. Hidden Power Ice deals with Flying- and Dragon-types like Gliscor, the Landorus formes, Garchomp, and Dragonite. Thunder Wave can be used over Hidden Power Ice to paralyze setup sweepers and fast threats that can't be effectively slowed down with Sticky Web, most notably Dragonite, Galarian Zapdos, Mega Aerodactyl, opposing Mega Pinsir, and Volcarona, without having to rely on Thunder to do so. This comes at the cost of losing coverage against Pokemon that resist both Thunder and Energy Ball, however. Sticky Web lowers the amount of Quiver Dance boosts needed for Volcarona to outspeed Regieleki, Unburden Sneasler, and Sand Rush Excadrill, making its setup more efficient. Sticky Web also allows choice Scarf users like Kleavor and Buzzwole to outspeed those Pokemon, limiting the amount of revenge killing options against them and improving their effectiveness against Fire- and Rock-types by taking care of Choice Scarf Blacephalon, Hisuian Arcanine, and Iron Boulder. Sticky Web gives Mega Pinsir more opportunities to use Return instead of Quick Attack to increase its damage output or Earthquake to KO Pokemon that would usually threaten it like Choice Scarf Nihilego and Hisuian Arcanine. Scizor can OHKO or force Diancie out before it can Mega Evolve to allow Galvantula to set up Sticky Web against Fairy- and Rock-teams.
