Swords Dance (Ghost).description: With its high Attack stat, powerful STAB combination, access to Swords Dance, and a great ability in Weak Armor, Ceruledge becomes an incredible wallbreaker for Ghost teams, hitting walls like Heatran, Hisuian Goodra, and Alolan Muk. At +2, Poltergeist outright OHKOs non-Unaware Clodsire and OHKO Mega Sableye, Swampert, and Heatran after a layer of Spikes. Bitter Blade allows Ceruledge to deal with Steel-types like Ferrothorn, Celesteela, and Mega Scizor while restoring its HP, letting it reactivate Focus Sash if not already consumed. Shadow Sneak allows Ceruledge to revenge kill weakened threats like Barraskewda, Iron Boulder, and opposing Ceruledge while also letting it clean opposing Ghost teams. Focus Sash guarantees that Ceruledge activates Weak Armor if it's hit with a physical attack while setting up with Swords Dance. Weak Armor's activation allows Ceruledge to outspeed faster threats like Mega Lopunny and Choice Scarf users like Meowscarada, Iron Boulder, and the Landorus formes. Mimikyu handles Dark-types like Mandibuzz, Ting-Lu, and Hydreigon, and, in return, Ceruledge can deal with Steel- and Poison-types like Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Mega Venusaur. Sinistcha boasts Water and Ground resistances, which allow it to check foes like Ogerpon-W, Urshifu-R, and Great Tusk. Mega Sableye provides entry hazard control, allowing Ceruledge to maintain its Focus Sash. Galarian Corsola and Brambleghast set entry hazards, which makes it easier for Ceruledge to break through bulky foes. Additionally, Brambleghast provides entry hazard removal with Rapid Spin while also providing the same resistances as Sinistcha. Hisuian Zoroark, Gengar, and Gholdengo are excellent partners that help Ceruledge against physical walls like Archaludon, Toxapex, and Great Tusk. In return, Ceruledge deals with special walls such as Clodsire, Blissey, Swampert, and Hisuian Goodra.

Swords Dance (Fire).description: Ceruledge is a strong late-game sweeper on Fire teams that checks Ghost- and Psychic-types thanks to its powerful STAB moves, setup in Swords Dance, and a great ability in Weak Armor, punishing physical attackers that hit it. At +2, Ceruledge 2HKOes Great Tusk and has a good chance to OHKO Gliscor after Stealth Rock damage with Poltergeist. Shadow Sneak allows Ceruledge to take out boosted albeit weakened Pokemon like Dragonite, Alolan Raichu, Iron Boulder, and opposing Ceruledge. With Focus Sash, Ceruledge ensures its Weak Armor is activated from most physical attacks, and it lets Ceruledge set up Swords Dance once. Cinderace and Torkoal are great partners for Ceruledge, as they provide entry hazard control with Court Change and Rapid Spin, respectively, so that its Focus Sash is kept intact. Additionally, Torkoal sets up sun to further boost Ceruledge's Bitter Blade and Stealth Rock to aid its sweeping, while Cinderace targets Dark-types such as Ting-Lu, Hydreigon, and Tyranitar, which can pose challenges to Ceruledge's sweeping. Wallbreakers such as Choice Band Victini and Mega Charizard X remove bulky Pokemon that Ceruledge dislikes. Victini takes on Water-types such as Tapu Fini, Urshifu-R, and Dondozo, while Mega Charizard X breaks past Heatran. In return, Victini appreciates Ceruledge handling Psychic-types like Iron Boulder and Mega Latias. Hisuian Arcanine revenge kills boosted sweepers such as Roaring Moon so that Ceruledge can sweep, and it can threaten Flying-types such as Galarian Moltres and Zapdos. Ceruledge can also enable other sweepers and cleaners such as Volcarona by removing Pokemon that threaten them such as Skeledirge so they can start their own sweep.

Entry Hazard Support (Rock).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Belly Drum.description: Cetitan, with its combination of Slush Rush and Belly Drum, is an exceptional wallbreaker and setup sweeper for Ice teams. Normalium Z allows Cetitan to use Z-Belly Drum, which gives it easier setup opportunities. Icicle Crash is the preferred STAB move because of its higher Base Power and the ability to ignore contact effects like Skarmory's Rocky Helmet and Ferrothorn's Iron Barbs; alternatively, the weaker Ice Spinner can be used for its higher accuracy. Earthquake targets Steel- and Fire-types like Gholdengo, Archaludon, Heatran, and Victini as well as Toxapex. Alternatively, Knock Off provides Cetitan with a way to threaten Slowbro and Rotom-W. Ice Shard, after a Belly Drum boost, allows Cetitan to pick off Choice Scarf foes like Sneasler and Iron Boulder, which outspeed it even in snow. A Jolly nature can also be used to allow Cetitan to outspeed Choice Scarf users like Blacephalon, Iron Moth, and Iron Treads in snow. Alolan Ninetales is an essential teammate for its ability to set snow and provide Aurora Veil support, facilitating Cetitan's sweeping capabilities. Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales also break through bulky Water-types like Slowbro and Rotom-W, which Cetitan may struggle against. With entry hazard support from Piloswine and Cloyster, Cetitan can OHKO threats like Skarmory, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn. Furthermore, Cloyster also provides hazard removal with Rapid Spin, increasing Cetitan's longevity.

Curse.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Water Absorb (Ground).description: Due to its incredible bulk and the ability to neutralize Water-type moves with Water Absorb, Clodsire is a staple for Ground teams, as it is able to stop threats such as Pelipper, Tapu Fini, and Rotom-W. Poison Jab not only spreads status but also lets it hit Grass- and Fairy-type Pokemon such as Tapu Bulu, Ogerpon-W, and Enamorus. Pairing Haze up with Icium Z allows Clodsire the ability to recover any damage from setup sweepers such as Volcarona, Ogerpon-W, and Kommo-o. The given EV spread allows Clodsire avoid a 2KHO from Choice Scarf Meowscarada with Flower Trick, unboosted Ogerpon-W with Horn Leech, and Choice Scarf Greninja with Ice Beam. Landorus provides an immunity to Ground-type moves that threaten Clodsire and offensively threatens Pokemon like Tapu Bulu, Celebi, and Archaludon. Hippowdon is a phenomenal defensive teammate, as it provides Stealth Rock support along with setting sand upon switching in. Hippowdon also defensively supports Clodsire by checking the likes of Ceruledge, Great Tusk, and Iron Hands. Excadrill, in conjunction with sand, is a powerful wallbreaker for Clodsire that can outspeed many Pokemon and deal raw damage with a Choice Band, checking threats such as Tapu Lele, Greninja, and Mega Gallade. Garchomp is an effective teammate that assists by checking Dragon-type threats such as Kommo-o and Kyurem. Mamoswine is another great teammate for Clodsire, as its Ice typing and powerful STAB moves assists in checking threats like the Landorus formes and Dragonite. Both Mamoswine and Garchomp deal offensive pressure to Steel- and Flying types such as Celesteela and Corviknight, which Clodsire cannot do on its own.

Unaware (Poison).description: Clodsire is an incredible specially defensive wall for Poison teams thanks to its solid stats and ability in Unaware, making it a solid check into special threats such as Hydreigon, Volcarona, and Gholdengo. Low Kick is used to break Hydreigon's Substitute along with popping Air Balloon from Heatran, while Poison Jab can be used to spread poison and do consistent damage to Flying-types like Zapdos and Tornadus-T. Clodsire's access to both Spikes and Stealth Rock provides it with good opportunities to set entry hazards, with Stealth Rock being preferred because it damages every Pokemon. Alternatively, Curse can patch up Clodsire's poor physical stats and make it a win condition. Mega Venusaur serves as a great defensive compliment to Clodsire with its ability to handle Water- and Ground-types like Barraskewda, Urshifu-R, Great Tusk, and Excadrill. Alolan Muk supports Clodsire by dealing with special attackers that threaten Clodsire like Latios, Tapu Lele, and Celebrate Victini. Crobat provides a solid Ground immunity, Defog to remove entry hazards while checking threats like Mega Gallade and Ogerpon-W, and Toxic to help outlast opponents. Choice Scarf Nihilego supports Clodsire by removing Ice- and Flying-types like Weavile, Mega Aerodactyl, the Landorus formes, and Mega Charizard Y. Choice Scarf Sneasler can help remove problematic faster threats like Choice Scarf Excadrill, Weavile, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele while greatly appreciating Clodsire's hazards to damage Porygon2 and Rotom-W, along with its ability to use Switcheroo to force an unwanted Choice Scarf onto targets like Corviknight.

Defensive Utility (Fighting).description: Great Tusk fills a crucial set of roles on Fighting teams and provides great role compression, being the type's premier Stealth Rock + Rapid Spin user. Knock Off furthers Great Tusk's capabilities, enabling it to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Crobat and Zapdos as they both come into Great Tusk's Earthquake and use Defog. Furthermore, Knock Off also allows Great Tusk to hit Ghost-types, such as Air Balloon Gholdengo. Earthquake combined with Great Tusk's Electric immunity and general bulk allows Great Tusk to stop threats such as Regieleki and Mega Charizard X from running through Fighting teams. Taunt can be run as an alternative option over Rapid Spin to prevent threats such as Ting-Lu and Skarmory from setting entry hazards or Defog users like Corviknight from removing Great Tusk's Stealth Rock. Leftovers grants Great Tusk longevity, while Heavy-Duty Boots provides safe entry, allowing it to use Rapid Spin without worrying about hazard damage. The given EV spreads maximize Great Tusk's physical bulk; 120 Speed EVs are preferred to let Great Tusk outspeed Modest Volcanion, but 96 Speed EVs can be used instead to further increase its bulk while still allowing Great Tusk to outspeed threats such as Latios and Iron Moth after a Rapid Spin. Sneasler serves as an excellent teammate with its incredible Speed and Poison typing, enabling it to handle Fairy- and Grass-types, such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Bulu, and Breloom. Iron Valiant can threaten opposing Great Tusk and Dark-types like Sableye and Mandibuzz with Moonblast, allowing for Great Tusk to reliably get Stealth Rock up. Iron Valiant also uses coverage moves such as Thunderbolt to deal with Slowbro and Mega Charizard Y while appreciating Great Tusk's handling of Poison-types, such as Sneasler and Galarian Slowking. Mega Gallade can check Poison- and Fighting-type threats such as Mega Venusaur and Keldeo. Kommo-o appreciates Great Tusk keeping hazards off the field and, in response, can set up safely with Clangorous Soulblaze, enabling it to overcome Flying and Water teams that greatly threaten Great Tusk. Assault Vest Iron Hands can threaten Water- and Flying-types such as Greninja, Pelipper, and Tornadus-T while appreciating Great Tusk's Stealth Rock, enabling it to 2HKO physically defensive Toxapex.

Choiced Attacker (Fighting).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Bulk Up (Ground).description: Great Tusk is a deadly wallbreaker on Ground teams, possessing excellent stats, a potent STAB combination, and access to utility moves like Knock Off and Rapid Spin. Close Combat threatens Ice- and Dark-types such as Baxcalibur, Hydreigon, and Hisuian Samurott as well as OHKOing walls like Celesteela, Corviknight, Mega Scizor, and Rotom-W with the aid of Fightinium Z after a Bulk Up boost, easing the Steel matchup for Great Tusk's team. Earthquake hits Pokemon like Skeledirge, Gholdengo, and Toxapex, while Ice Spinner nails Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Zapdos, allowing Great Tusk to boast unresisted coverage in combination with Close Combat. Rapid Spin allows Great Tusk to gain a Speed boost to easily snowball against slower teams and remove entry hazards for teammates; however, Knock Off is great for Air Balloon Gholdengo and weakened Slowbro as well as generally forcing progress against teams by removing their items. Gastrodon and Clodsire are essential teammates for Great Tusk due to their immunities to Water-type attacks, letting them fend off Barraskewda, Urshifu-R, and Keldeo. Gastrodon also has an appreciated neutrality to Ice-type attacks, letting it check Choice Scarf Weavile, and Clodsire is neutral to Grass-type attacks, letting it wall Meowscarada. It can also wall Fairy-types like Tapu Koko, Tapu Fini, and Iron Valiant. Furthermore, Gastrodon and Clodsire provide chip damage via Toxic and entry hazards, wearing down walls like Slowbro, Swampert, and Mantine that give Great Tusk a hard time. Landorus forms a potent wallbreaking core with Great Tusk, breaking Slowbro, Dondozo, and Mandibuzz as well as offering Gravity, letting Great Tusk more easily spam Earthquake. In return, Landorus appreciates Great Tusk threatening Ice Shard users like Mamoswine and Baxcalibur. Mega Steelix is an excellent teammate, as it fights off Azumarill, Weavile, and Alolan Ninetales, making it a huge asset in the Fairy and Ice matchups. Ting-Lu forms an entry hazard-stacking core with Gastrodon and Clodsire, wearing down teams exponentially faster with the help of Whirlwind. Additionally, Ting-Lu switches into attacks from revenge killers like Blacephalon, Latias, and Hisuian Zoroark. Mamoswine appreciates Great Tusk breaking Celesteela and Corviknight; in return, Mamoswine utilizes Thick Fat to fight the aforementioned Ice-types and provides speed control with Choice Scarf, outpacing Mega Diancie, Enamorus, and Tapu Koko. Choice Scarf Iron Treads outpaces and OHKOes the aforementioned Fairy-types, most notably Iron Valiant, and provides pivoting support via Volt Switch.

Offensive Spinner (Steel).description: Air Balloon Iron Treads provides Steel teams with some speed control, outspeeding dangerous threats such as Victini and Landorus always and Zeraora when Electric Terrain is active. Ice Spinner synergizes well with Earthquake, dissuading Gliscor and Latias from coming into Iron Treads's attacks. Knock Off weakens walls such as Rotom-W, Staraptor, and Celesteela that wall Iron Treads. Alternatively, Stone Edge is an option to remove Mega Charizard Y, Volcarona, and Mega Pinsir. Rapid Spin clears entry hazards and gives Iron Treads enough Speed to clean up weakened Electric, Ground, and Dragon teams. Air Balloon lets Iron Treads safely switch into Excadrill and Mamoswine and creates uncomfortable situations for Ground and Bug teams due to its initial immunity to Ground-type moves and Sticky Web. Soft Sand allows Earthquake to 2HKO Mega Sableye after Stealth Rock damage, preventing Mega Sableye from switching in to spinblock Iron Treads. As Iron Treads is relatively weak, stallbreakers like Nasty Plot Gholdengo and Swords Dance Mega Scizor are excellent for weakening or removing walls; Gholdengo beats Archaludon and Mega Sableye and Mega Scizor deals with Ferrothorn and Slowbro. Mega Scizor also provides great neutralities that allow it to switch into Fighting- and Ground-types like Mega Lopunny and Clodsire with ease, while Gholdengo handles Body Press users like Skarmory and Fighting-types like Sneasler. Choice Scarf teammates such as Gholdengo, Heatran, and Archaludon supplement Iron Treads's speed control, as they outspeed and pick off Mega Gallade, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny, which threaten to OHKO Iron Treads. Heatran also provides a Fire immunity and hazards or Toxic to further chip down opposing teams. Physically defensive Archaludon and Ferrothorn are great for dealing with Ogerpon-W, which can use Iron Treads as setup fodder, and support Iron Treads through debilitating foes with Thunder Wave and setting hazards. Celesteela and Skarmory are Ground-immune teammates that can switch into Mega Diancie or Choice Band Excadrill to avoid Iron Treads's Air Balloon from breaking prematurely; Celesteela is also a decent mixed wall that smothers Dragon and Fairy teams, while Skarmory has access to hazards and Whirlwind to further weaken opposing teams for Iron Treads.

Choice Scarf (Steel).description: Iron Treads is a great Choice Scarf user on Steel teams due to its great Speed tier, notably allowing it to outpace Volcarona after a Quiver Dance and Mega Charizard X after a Dragon Dance. It also has a great variety of coverage moves, aiding against Landorus and the aforementioned Fire-types. Earthquake targets threats such as Heatran, Zeraora, Sneasler, and Gholdengo. Iron Head hits Fairy-types like Tapu Bulu, Iron Valiant, and Enamorus, while Volt Switch allows Iron Treads to maintain momentum and pivot out of unfavorable switch-ins like Pelipper and Slowbro. Ice Spinner hits Ground- and Dragon-types such as Landorus, Dragonite, and Garchomp while also aiding in the Flying matchup, removing Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Gliscor. Furthermore, Ice Spinner removes Psychic Terrain for Mega Scizor, which relies on Bullet Punch. Stone Edge threatens Fire- and Flying-types like Volcarona, Articuno, and Mega Charizard Y. Alternatively, Knock Off pressures defensive switch-ins such as Rotom-W, Celesteela, and Ferrothorn while also being Iron Treads's best move against Air Balloon Gholdengo and Latias. Iron Treads can provide emergency entry hazard removal via Rapid Spin for faster-paced Steel teams. Hard Press is a niche option to remove frail targets like Meowscarada; however, Iron Head allows Iron Treads to revenge kill weakened Pokemon. Gholdengo is an excellent teammate that greatly capitalizes on Z-Moves, offers a Fighting-type immunity, and acts as a situational Ground-type immunity with Air Balloon. It also removes walls like Slowbro, Corviknight, and defensive Great Tusk. In return, Iron Treads offers a valuable answer to Fire-types such as Cinderace, Volcanion, and Victini. Heatran absorbs Fire-type attacks from faster threats like Choice Scarf Blacephalon and Iron Moth, in addition to setting up Stealth Rock to wear down switch-ins for Iron Treads. Celesteela and Corviknight offer a Ground-type immunity, walling Sand Rush Excadrill and Hippowdon. Furthermore, Corviknight provides slow pivoting via U-turn, while Celesteela pressures foes with residual chip damage using Toxic and Leech Seed. In exchange, Iron Treads threatens Electric-type Pokemon like Tapu Koko, Regieleki, and Sandy Shocks, as well as Fire teams, removing Hisuian Arcanine and Ceruledge once its Focus Sash has been broken. Ferrothorn is a great buffer against Water- and Ground- types like Gastrodon, Swampert, Mamoswine, and Slowking. Additionally, Ferrothorn boasts an array of utility options such as Leech Seed, Knock Off, and Spikes, wearing down Iron Treads's switch-ins and allowing for a free Stone Edge moveslot.

Assault Vest (Electric).description: Iron Hands is a great addition to an Electric team, as its bulk combined with an Assault Vest allows it to take hits from Pokémon that Electric teams otherwise struggle against like Kyurem and Landorus-T while also pivoting into frail teammates. Drain Punch is Iron Hands’s only form of recovery and is capable of dealing blows to Pokemon like Hisuian Goodra and Ferrothorn. Ice Punch allows Iron Hands to threaten Ground-types like Landorus and Garchomp, as it can take an attack from Landorus and an unboosted Garchomp. Rock Slide allows Iron Hands to OHKO Blacephalon, Volcarona, and Mega Charizard Y, while Thunder Punch still deals with Mega Charizard Y while also dealing with Water-types and bulkier Flying-types such as Manaphy, Slowbro, and Corviknight. Volt Switch allows it to pivot out of checks like Tapu Lele and Mega Sableye and into Pokemon like Tapu Koko and Regieleki that can deal damage to the opposing team, while Earthquake allows it to deal with Gholdengo and opposing Iron Hands, as they would wall it otherwise. The EV spread allows Iron Hands to avoid an OHKO from +2 Dragonite's Earthquake or a 2HKO from Mega Charizard Y, allowing Iron Hands to retaliate with an Ice Punch or Rock Slide. The EV spread also allows it to OHKO Garchomp with Ice Punch while in Electric Terrain due to Quark Drive set by its teammates. Tapu Koko is an amazing partner with Iron Hands, as it can take care of Mega Sableye and Mamoswine while also setting Electric Terrain, which allows Iron Hands to hit harder through Pokemon like Toxapex. Iron Hands is weak to Ground-type Pokemon like Mamoswine and Landorus-T, so Pokemon with a Ground immunity like Zapdos and Rotom-W can ease some pressure on Iron Hands while also taking some hits defensively. Both can also form a pivoting core with Iron Hands to pivot frail teammates in on both physical and special attackers, increasing the amount of times these teammates can come in, and both also have the opportunity to use Defog, allowing Iron Hands to avoid taking entry hazard damage. Rotom-W in particular can cripple physical attackers that Iron Hands can’t handle, like Mamoswine and Garchomp, with Will-O-Wisp. Regieleki is also a great teammate, as it can capitalize on Iron Hands's removal of special walls for it to sweep.

Assault Vest (Fighting).description: Iron Hands serves a solid role on Fighting teams, being the type's premier Assault Vest user that can take on threatening special attackers such as Mega Charizard Y, Greninja, and Iron Valiant. Thunder Punch breaks through problematic Flying- and Water-types like Tornadus-T, Mega Pidgeot, and Manaphy. Ice Punch deals with Ground- and Grass-types switching in to take on Iron Hands's Thunder Punch such as Gliscor and Celebi. Drain Punch provides Iron Hands with a form of recovery while still enabling it to check threats such as Hydreigon. Finally, Volt Switch allows Iron Hands to be a slow pivot for Fighting teams that can safely bring in frail offensive threats like Sneasler. Alternatively, Heavy Slam can be used to let Iron Hands crush Fairy-types like Mega Diancie. The chosen EV spread allows for Iron Hands to OHKO uninvested Tornadus-T while maintaining bulk. For teammates, Iron Valiant is a special attacking threat that can break past physical walls like Slowbro and Mega Sableye that hamper Iron Hands. Iron Hands appreciates Mega Gallade being able to handle Poison-types such as Mega Venusaur and Okidogi, which wall it. Great Tusk provides Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock support to help with Iron Hands's longevity and make it more threatening, the latter potentially allowing it to 2HKO physically bulky Toxapex. Sneasler can handle Fairy-types that Iron Hands cannot such as Tapu Bulu and Tapu Lele while appreciating Iron Hands's slow Volt Switch to safely get it on the field. Since Keldeo is able to deal with Ground-types such as Great Tusk and the Landorus formes, which threaten Iron Hands immensely, it serves as an excellent teammate. Similarly, Hisuian Lilligant, after a boost, can break past Ground-types such as Swampert and Sand Rush Excadrill along with Water-types that can overwhelm Iron Hands like Rotom-W. Kommo-o helps Iron Hands with breaking through walls such as Scizor and Gholdengo that can prove problematic for it.

Choice Scarf (Poison).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Fire).description: Choice Scarf Iron Moth makes for a great cleaner on Fire teams by virtue of its diverse moveset and being able to outspeed Mega Swampert and non-Choice Scarf Greninja. Energy Ball handles Water-, Rock-, and Ground-types like Greninja, Mega Diancie, and Great Tusk. Sludge Wave targets the Ogerpon formes as well as Fairy-types such as Enamorus and Tapu Koko. Dazzling Gleam covers threats such as Hydreigon and Kommo-o. Torkoal sets up sun to boost Iron Moth's Fiery Dance to make it a more terrifying snowballing option and Stealth Rock to aid Iron Moth's cleaning, notably breaking Focus Sash and Sturdy from their users. Both Torkoal and Cinderace also serve as entry hazard control with Rapid Spin and Court Change, respectively, and the latter can bring Iron Moth in with U-turn to keep momentum. Mega Charizard X and Hisuian Arcanine pair well with Iron Moth, as they take on Heatran and Blissey, which otherwise wall Iron Moth. Heatran itself serves as a great partner, as due to its access to Magma Storm and Taunt, it can shut down and eliminate walls such as Toxapex. In return, Heatran appreciates Iron Moth taking on Ground-types such as Great Tusk, Mega Swampert, and Gastrodon. Thanks to Iron Moth's ability to take on bulky foes such as Mega Sableye and Tapu Fini as well as speedy Pokemon such as Iron Treads and Choice Scarf Enamorus, it can enable late-game sweepers such as Ceruledge and Volcarona to begin their own sweep.

Z-Move (Ghost).description: Having a typing with a lot of relevant resistances, an immunity to status moves thanks to Good as Gold, and great longevity by virtue of having Recover, Gholdengo is a potent stallbreaker for Ghost teams. Shadow Ball hits most foes for neutral damage, with Never-Ending Nightmare at +2 OHKOing foes such as Mega Sableye, Galarian Slowking, and Corviknight. Make It Rain lets Gholdengo hit foes such as Alolan Muk, Mandibuzz, and Kommo-o, as well as OHKO Ice- and Fairy-type foes such as Mamoswine, Alolan Ninetales, and Iron Valiant, and at +2, this move OHKOes Gliscor, Hippowdon, and Ursaluna. The given EV spread allows Gholdengo to outspeed Adamant Mamoswine and avoid a 2HKO from Mega Scizor's Knock Off, Ogerpon-C's Knock Off after Stealth Rock, and Choice Specs Tapu Lele's Thunderbolt. Mega Sableye forms a good defensive core with Gholdengo, as Mega Sableye mitigates its vulnerability to Dark- and Ghost-type foes such as Meowscarada, Greninja, and Hisuian Zoroark, while Gholdengo handles Fairy-types including Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Sinistcha can switch into Ground-types such as Garchomp, Mega Swampert, and Great Tusk that Gholdengo is vulnerable to. Fire-types such as Ceruledge and Skeledirge are solid partners that can check other Fire-types that force out Gholdengo such as Cinderace, Victini, and Volcarona.

Choice Scarf (Steel).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Mixed Wall (Dark).description: Ting-Lu finds itself a home on Dark teams as a sturdy special wall and entry hazard setter, capable of staving off foes like Mega Charizard Y, Nasty Plot Tornadus-T, Tapu Koko, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and threatening them out. Heavy Slam alongside 32 Attack EVs allows Ting-Lu to OHKO Choice Scarf Tapu Lele as well as dissuade other Fairy-types such as Tapu Bulu from switching in for free. Ruination allows Ting-Lu to deal consistent damage to opposing walls such as Corviknight and Porygon2 and force them to use up their recovery moves' PP, softening them up in the long run for a teammate like Meowscarada or Hydreigon. Rock Slide allows Ting-Lu to OHKO Mega Charizard Y and Quiver Dance Volcarona, which can be an issue if not running Whirlwind. Whirlwind allows Ting-Lu to stop setup sweepers such as the aforementioned Volcarona as well as Swords Dance Garchomp, Nasty Plot + Substitute Hydreigon, and Z-Celebrate Victini from using it as setup fodder, while both Spikes and Stealth Rock allow Ting-Lu to chip down defensive pieces like the previously talked-about Porygon2 as well as Ferrothorn, Hisuian Goodra, and Clodsire every time they attempt to answer a threat. Offensive teammates such as Meowscarada, Hydreigon, and Weavile appreciate Ting-Lu setting hazards to chip down their answers into range of their attacks. Alolan Muk provides a Fairy neutrality to answer threats like Tapu Lele and Enamorus alongside Knock Off support to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes like Corviknight, Tornadus-T, and Staraptor. Mega Sableye offers hazard control to let Ting-Lu maximize its longevity and come in safely to check threats, combats Mega Gallade and Sneasler thanks to its Fighting immunity, blocks Rapid Spin from the likes of Iron Treads and Terapagos, and provides Knock Off support to help whittle down the aforementioned Heavy-Duty Boots users. Hisuian Samurott pairs nicely with Ting-Lu if not running Spikes thanks to its ability to set up Spikes itself with Ceaseless Edge while appreciating the general chip damage Ting-Lu's hazards do to its answers like Tapu Bulu.

Physically Defensive (Ground).description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Choice Scarf (Dragon).description: Roaring Moon is the fastest Choice Scarf user Dragon teams have access to, blitzing past opposing Choice Scarf threats like Latias and Enamorus, while also outspeeding Iron Valiant under Electric Terrain. Iron Head targets Mega Diancie and Alolan Ninetales; though it doesn't OHKO Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Mega Altaria, Iron Head deals enough damage to pick these Pokemon off late-game. U-turn lets Roaring Moon keep up the momentum against walls that usually switch into it, such as Ferrothorn, Skarmory, and Archaludon. Knock Off, aside from dealing with Ghost-types like Blacephalon and Gengar, also strips switch-ins like Staraptor, Rotom-W, and Corviknight of their items, making it easier for Dragon teams to overwhelm these defensive Pokemon late-game. Roaring Moon is unfortunately still outsped by even faster Choice Scarf users like Greninja and Meowscarada, or Swift Swim and Sand Rush Pokemon like Barraskewda and Excadrill, so switch-ins to these threats like Hisuian Goodra, Archaludon, or Mega Latias are appreciated. Archaludon and Hisuian Goodra also help a lot against a plethora of threats, with Archaludon providing Stealth Rock while weathering physical assaults from Mega Altaria, Weavile, and opposing Roaring Moon. Whereas Hisuian Goodra takes minimal damage from Tapu Lele and SubRoost Kyurem while also having the ability to phaze out threats Roaring Moon struggles to handle like Autotomize Celesteela or Volcarona. Kyurem and Z-move Kommo-o wear down the defensive cores of Water, Flying, Poison, Steel, and Normal teams which can provide an opening for Roaring Moon to clean up these teams late-game. Mega Altaria and Mega Latias love Roaring Moon removing Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant, as this opens up an opportunity for them to overwhelm Fairy and Fighting teams late-game. Garchomp wears down Steel- and Poison-types like Skarmory and Toxapex that Roaring Moon has trouble with, sets Spikes, and can phaze out threats like Volcarona and Unburden Sneasler that take advantage of Roaring Moon.

Dragon Dance (Dragon).description: Roaring Moon capitalizes on opponents' overfamiliarity with its Choice Scarf set to set up Dragon Dance and overwhelm opposing teams. +1 Z-Crunch OHKOes Rotom-W, Slowbro, and physically defensive Gholdengo, OHKOes Unaware Skeledirge normally, and OHKOes Celesteela after some chip damage. Alternatively, Knock Off removes items from checks like Corviknight and Rotom-W before Roaring Moon sets up and sweeps later. Knock Off is also preferred on Heavy-Duty Boots sets, as it offers more utility and upfront damage. Earthquake complements its Roaring Moon's Dark-type STAB attack by dealing with Fairy- and Dark-types like Tapu Koko and Alolan Muk. Substitute gives Roaring Moon safety while setting up, turning Slowbro and Toxapex into setup fodder, while Iron Head enables it to clean up Fairy teams at +1 if it finds time to set up; Iron Head also OHKOes Mega Diancie at +0. Mega Altaria with Dragon Dance or Agility complements Roaring Moon, dealing with Fighting- and Dragon-types like Iron Valiant, Kommo-o, and opposing Mega Altaria that Roaring Moon struggles with. Mega Altaria can also use Will-O-Wisp to prevent Celesteela, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu from breaking Roaring Moon's Substitute in one hit. Choice Scarf Latias handles Fighting-types like Iron Valiant and Mega Lopunny, and it provides Healing Wish to provide Roaring Moon with a second chance to sweep. Archaludon and Hisuian Goodra provide crucial neutralities to Ice and Fairy, and they deal with Weavile and Meowscarada and Tapu Lele and Kyurem, respectively. Teammates that wear down Steel teams like Garchomp, Mega Latios, Walking Wake, and Kommo-o are appreciated; in return, Roaring Moon tears through their checks in Celesteela, Alolan Muk, and Galarian Slowking.

Swords Dance (Fairy).description: Iron Valiant's combination of stats, typing, and coverage makes it an excellent wallbreaker for Fairy teams, capable of outrunning Mega Diancie, Nihilego, and Iron Treads. At +2 Attack, All-Out Pummeling OHKOes troublesome walls such as physically defensive Celesteela and Corviknight. Spirit Break notably breaks Mega Sableye, enabling Iron Valiant to greatly pressure Dark and Ghost teams. Knock Off deals with Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Aegislash, allowing Iron Valiant to heavily dent Steel. It also removes important items from Clodsire, Klefki, and Toxapex. Shadow Sneak can be used over Knock Off to pick off weakened foes like Blacephalon. Iron Valiant loves Klefki's ability to set dual screens and Spikes, as this allows Iron Valiant to set up more easily and deal with bulkier cores better. Tapu Lele sets Psychic Terrain, neutralizing Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch, and it also deals with Poison-types Iron Valiant has a hard time with, such as Mega Venusaur and Toxapex. Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain activates Iron Valiant's Quark Drive, letting it outspeed the likes of Mega Lopunny and Mega Swampert under rain. Tapu Bulu improves the Water and Ground matchups and removes bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Dondozo. Mega Diancie and Azumarill love Iron Valiant's ability to soften walls, as it allows them to clean up late-game.

Choice Scarf (Fighting).description: Iron Valiant is one of Fighting teams' best assets with amazing qualities between its typing, Speed, and offenses. Choice Scarf accentuates its Speed further and lets it outspeed many threats to Fighting teams such as Tornadus-T, Tapu Koko, and Choice Scarf users such as Tapu Lele and Galarian Zapdos. Its STAB Moonblast is one of its best qualities, being able to easily beat Mega Sableye and OHKO most opposing Fighting- and Dragon-types such as Buzzwole and Mega Altaria. Thunderbolt is great coverage to hit Flying- and Water-types like Tornadus-T and Toxapex that otherwise wall Iron Valiant, while Energy Ball lets it deal with Mega Swampert, which it can outspeed even under rain, Rotom-W, and Gastrodon more easily. Shadow Ball prevents Iron Valiant from being walled by Gholdengo, Skeledirge, and Aegislash while also improving the Psychic matchup. Knock Off and Trick cripple defensive switch-ins such as Toxapex, Celesteela, and Clodsire by removing or replacing important items and forcing them to go without passive recovery or be Choice locked. Iron Valiant is also a great asset in the Fairy and Electric matchups, as it uses opposing Tapu Koko's Electric Surge to activate its own Quark Drive and outspeed even Regieleki and Alolan Raichu under Electric Terrain. Iron Valiant appreciates support from Mega Gallade, as it easily takes care of Poison-types like Clodsire, Mega Venusaur, and Alolan Muk. Iron Hands and Great Tusk are great teammates for the Electric matchup while also beating the likes of Toxapex, Galarian Moltres, and Gholdengo. Cobalion and Great Tusk can set up Stealth Rock and even clear entry hazards in the case of the latter. Cobalion also helps against Fairy-types such as Tapu Bulu and Tapu Lele, while Great Tusk helps deal with Tapu Koko and Assault Vest Iron Hands. Choice Band Urshifu-R is a great ally to beat Fire-types such as Volcarona and Skeledirge and Ground-types such as Landorus-T and Excadrill. Kommo-o deals with bulky Water-, Fire-, and Grass-types like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Mega Venusaur with its massive Clangorus Soulblaze in conjunction with Taunt. Breloom is also a natural counter to Water-types, being able to deal with Swampert, and hindering defensive walls such as Toxapex with Spore. Galarian Zapdos is another great teammate that can weaken foes and safely get in Iron Valiant with U-turn.

Choice Specs (Water).description:
The EV spread provides a Speed Protosynthesis boost under sun.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Calm Mind (Ghost).description: Sinistcha is the most physically defensive Ground-resistant Pokemon Ghost teams have access to, which is useful for dealing with Excadrill and Mega Swampert. It also pressures Grass-neutral Pokemon like Clodsire and Toxapex on Water and Ground teams with ease. Matcha Gotcha improves Sinistcha's longevity and lets it fish for burns against the aforementioned Pokemon neutral to Grass as well as common switch-ins like Celesteela and Alolan Muk. Substitute lets Sinistcha avoid status from Toxapex and gives it more turns to threaten a burn on would-be checks like Iron Hands and Mega Lopunny and chip down answers like Choice Specs Zapdos. Shadow Ball is usually preferred for its consistent damage output without relying on burns, but Hex lets Sinistcha further pressure opposing threats after they are burned. 96 Speed EVs let Sinistcha outspeed Adamant Azumarill, while the remaining EVs are poured into maximizing its bulk to weather Choice Band Excadrill, Ogerpon-W, and Mega Swampert better. Physical setup sweepers like Mimikyu and Ceruledge form a decent wallbreaking core with Sinistcha, dealing with special walls like Hisuian Goodra and Alolan Muk, while Sinistcha obliterates physical walls like Hippowdon and Great Tusk. Gholdengo loves Sinistcha's ability to remove Ground-types and in turn is able to wear down or remove Alolan Muk and Mantine, deal with prominent Knock Off users like Meowscarada if using a Z-Crystal, and take on Flying-types like Mega Aerodactyl and Articuno for it. Mega Sableye also absorbs Knock Off and can wear down opposing teams for Sinistcha with its ability to spread status and remove items.

Bulk Up (Poison).description:
52 Speed EVs outspeeds uninvested Rotom-W.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Swords Dance (Water).description: Ogerpon-W is a strong wallbreaker on Water teams by virtue of its great Attack, which can be further boosted by Swords Dance; great Speed; a unique resistance to Ground, improving that matchup; and a selection of coverage options it can choose from. Horn Leech not only lets Ogerpon-W recover HP, but it also targets the likes of Urshifu-R, Slowbro, and Mantine, which can otherwise shrug off an Ivy Cudgel. At +2, Play Rough targets Dragon- and Fighting-types such as Kyurem, Kommo-o, and Iron Hands. After a Swords Dance boost, Superpower is great against Steel-types like Hisuian Goodra, Archaludon, and Ferrothorn; unboosted, it also OHKOes Kyurem after Stealth Rock chip. Taunt shuts down passive walls such as Toxapex, Gastrodon, and Thunder Wave Archaludon to force them out and get the opportunity to set up, while after a boost, Knock Off targets Sinistcha. Swampert provides entry hazard support to help Ogerpon-W wallbreak and pivoting with Flip Turn; its Electric immunity improves the matchup against the type, handling the likes of Zeraora, Iron Hands, and Regieleki. Empoleon and Pelipper remove hazards in Defog so that Ogerpon-W does not get worn down. Additionally, Empoleon threatens Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele and Alolan Ninetales, as well as Tornadus-T and Kyurem, while Pelipper sets up rain to boost Ogerpon-W's Ivy Cudgel, handles Grass-types like Meowscarada and Mega Venusaur, and brings it in safely with U-turn. In return, Empoleon appreciates Ogerpon-W handling Ground-types such as Great Tusk and the Landorus formes, while Pelipper appreciates the removal of Hisuian Arcanine, the Landorus formes, and Gholdengo. Choice Scarf Tapu Fini, with its amazing bulk, handles fast Fighting- and Dragon-types like Iron Valiant, Mega Lopunny, and Dragon Dance Roaring Moon and can shift its Choice Scarf to walls like Toxapex and Clodsire with Trick so Ogerpon-W can handle them more easily. Choice Specs Greninja, with its colorful coverage boosted by Protean, handles a multitude of threats like opposing Ogerpon-W, Tapu Bulu, and Mega Venusaur. When paired with Pelipper, Ogerpon-W's wallbreaking opens up the door for rain-boosted sweepers and cleaners such as Mega Swampert and Barraskewda.

Setup Sweeper (Grass).description: Ogerpon-C is a formidable choice on Grass teams that holds its own over its Rock typing, coupled with it's amazing Attack and Speed, makes it a formidable threat to the Bug-, Fire-, Ice-, and Flying-types that threaten Grass teams such as Volcarona, Mega Charizard Y, Alolan Ninetales, and Tornadus-T with the powerful and accurate Ivy Cudgel. Swords Dance can boost Ogerpon-C's Attack to a threatening level, boosting Ivy Cudgel even more to break through formidable walls such as Corviknight and Celesteela. Horn Leech grants recovery for Ogerpon-C while also regaining Sturdy once it gets back to full. At +2, Superpower breaks through Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon like Archaludon, Heatran, and Hydreigon. Choice Scarf Meowscarada can handle any threatening Dragon-types for Ogerpon-C such as Roaring Moon, MegaAltaria, and Kommo-o with its Protean-boosted Play Rough while also removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Dragonite and Leftovers from Corviknight with Knock Off. Mega Venusaur is a defensive teammate for Ogerpon-C that can take threatening Fire- and Ice-type moves with its ability, Thick Fat, such as Meowscarada's Triple Axel. Ferrothorn is another defensive teammate that can provide entry hazard support and take on physical threats such as Melmetal and Weavile. Sinistcha is a great late-game setup sweeper that can become a wincon alongside Ogerpon-C with access to Calm Mind and Strength Sap. Breloom provides a form of priority with Technician-boosted Mach Punch and can put foes to sleep with Spore.

Swords Dance (Rock).description: With good stats and a part-Grass typing that lets it beat common threats to Rock such as Manaphy, Ursaluna, and Swampert, Ogerpon-C is a potent sweeper for Rock teams. Horn Leech is a STAB move that grants Ogerpon-C longevity, mitigating chip damage to more reliably trigger Sturdy, and it threatens common checks to Rock teams such as Gastrodon, Ting-Lu, and Rotom-W. Knock Off 2HKOes foes such as Sinistcha and Gholdengo while also removing Heavy-Duty Boots to make foes vulnerable to entry hazards. Superpower is an alternative option to hit Steel-types that could otherwise wall Ogerpon-C, and after a Swords Dance, it OHKOes Ferrothorn and, after Stealth Rock, Archaludon as well. Shuckle and Mega Diancie can set entry hazards to let Ogerpon-C more easily apply offensive pressure; the former's Sticky Web allows Ogerpon-C to outspeed foes such as Mega Gallade, Zeraora, and Mega Lopunny. As Ogerpon-C struggles with taking care of Fighting-types such as Kommo-o, Mega Lopunny, and Sneasler, partners like Mega Diancie and Iron Boulder, which can simultaneously take advantage of Shuckle's Sticky Web and offensively check these threats, pair well. Ogerpon-C can struggle with Steel-types as well, so allies that can more easily overwhelm them such as Hisuian Arcanine and Z-Crystal Iron Boulder are also appreciated.

Physically Defensive (Dragon).description: With its secondary Steel typing, remarkable physical bulk, and access to a great ability in Stamina, Archaludon becomes an exceptional physical wall for Dragon teams, capable of handling foes like Meowscarada, Weavile, and Roaring Moon. Flash Cannon targets problematic Fairy-types like Mimikyu and Mega Altaria, in addition to OHKOing Iron Valiant and Mega Diancie. Body Press synergizes with Stamina, providing Archaludon with a way to threaten Steel-, Dark-, and Ice-types like Hisuian Goodra, Roaring Moon, and Cetitan. Stealth Rock wears down foes, aiding against offensive threats like Enamorus and Ceruledge. Thunder Wave punishes switch-ins by slowing them down, making it easier for teammates to revenge kill them. Foul Play allows Archaludon to eliminate Ceruledge as well as punish other physical attackers like Ogerpon-W and Mega Scizor. Lastly, Protect allows Archaludon to capitalize on Leftovers recovery and potentially scout against Choice-locked foes like Tapu Lele and Greninja. The EV spread allows Archaludon to outspeed defensive Great Tusk and survive Mega Diancie's Earth Power. Due to its low Special Defense, Archaludon is threatened by special attackers like Tapu Lele, Kyurem, Hydreigon, and Greninja, making Hisuian Goodra a valuable teammate that can handle these foes. Mega Altaria, Latias, and Latios are excellent partners for their ability to deal with Fighting-types like Mega Gallade, Kommo-o, and Keldeo. Latias and Latios also provide a Ground immunity and, along with Kyurem, can deal with Ground-types like Clodsire and Hippowdon; Garchomp, Kommo-o, and Raging Bolt are exceptional wallbreakers that help take out foes like Volcarona, Gholdengo, Ferrothorn, and Celesteela. All of these Pokemon also help Archaludon deal with Toxapex.

Nasty Plot (Grass).description:
172 Speed EVs lets Hydrapple outspeed Pelipper.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

Calm Mind (Electric).description: Calm Mind Raging Bolt is a potent wallbreaker and setup sweeper for Electric teams, possessing a high Special Attack, excellent defenses, and incredible priority in Thunderclap to pick off faster foes like Sneasler and Ceruledge. With Devastating Drake, Raging Bolt breaks through bulkier targets like Mega Venusaur and Archaludon, and it also applies tremendous pressure on bulky Ground-types, having a high chance to KO Gliscor without a boost, OHKOing specially defensive Swampert at +1, and providing good odds to OHKO Water Absorb Clodsire at +1. With its typing, Raging Bolt switches in against foes like Mega Charizard Y and Ogerpon-W and threatens them out with its STAB moves. Thunderclap lets Raging Bolt revenge kill faster threats like Greninja and Enamorus as well as Iron Valiant at +1. 136 Speed EVs allow Raging Bolt to outspeed Jolly Ursaluna and specially defensive Heatran. Rotom-W and Zapdos provide crucial Ground-immune teammates for the team. Rotom-W can take on threats like Sand Rush Excadrill, Mega Swampert, and Choice Scarf Landorus-T, and Zapdos can remove foes like Ferrothorn and Tapu Bulu and serve an offensive or defensive role, assisting against Ground and Fighting teams. Tapu Koko threatens Dragon- and Dark-types like Latios, Hydreigon, and Weavile, and with Grass Knot and Hidden Power Ice, it helps in alleviating Ground matchups, removing threats like Landorus. Tapu Koko also sets Electric Terrain to boost Raging Bolt's Electric-type moves, most notably allowing it to OHKO bulkier threats like Mega Diancie and Galarian Darmanitan with +1 Thunderclap. Iron Hands and Choice Band Zeraora eliminate special walls like Hisuian Goodra and Blissey as well as Ferrothorn while also covering Ice- and Dark-types like Kyurem and Mega Tyranitar. Regieleki and Alolan Raichu offer valuable speed control. Regieleki possesses incredible natural Speed, outspeeding Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and +1 Volcarona, while Alolan Raichu can outspeed +1 Roaring Moon, Choice Scarf Meowscarada, and even Sand Rush Excadrill when under Electric Terrain. Raging Bolt appreciates entry hazard control from teammates like Rotom-W, Zapdos, and Regieleki.

Swords Dance (Rock).description: With the title of being one of Rock's fastest attackers, Iron Boulder can make use of Swords Dance and a Z-Move to become a threatening wallbreaker versus the likes of Fighting- and Steel-types such as Iron Hands with Shattered Psyche and Archaludon with All-Out Pummeling. Iron Boulder can use Shattered Psyche to tear through Fighting- and Poison-types such as Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Toxapex. Mighty Cleave and Close Combat complement each other, allowing Iron Boulder to deal with Volcarona, Hisuian Goodra, and Galarian Moltres. After a boost, All-Out Pummeling can even break the likes of Archaludon and Ting-Lu. Shuckle can easily set entry hazards to make it easier on Iron Boulder to set up and threaten defensive checks like Heatran. With its secondary Grass typing, Ogerpon-C can break through Water- and Ground-types like Hippowdon and Mega Swampert more easily while also being a secondary setup sweeper that pairs well with Iron Boulder. Mega Diancie, in conjunction with Iron Boulder, can break through Fighting and Dark teams with its Fairy typing and powerful Moonblast, being the best way to remove the likes of Mega Sableye. Thanks to its Fire typing, Hisuian Arcanine can assist in breaking through Steel- and Grass-types such as Gholdengo, Ferrothorn, and Tapu Bulu with Flare Blitz. Mega Aerodacty can assist in the matchup versus the likes of Excadrill once Sticky Web is set , assisting in removing the few foes that outspeed Iron Boulder.

Choice Scarf (Psychic).description: Choice Scarf Iron Boulder cleaves through speedy threats like opposing Choice Scarf users such as Meowscarada, Enamorus, and Roaring Moon as well as generally fast Pokemon like Ogerpon-W, Mega Lopunny, and Mega Aerodactyl. Close Combat smashes Steel-types aiming to take on Mighty Cleave such as Heatran and Hisuian Goodra and is Iron Boulder's main way to revenge kill the aforementioned Dark-types. Earthquake threatens Alolan Muk, which can swap in against Iron Boulder due to its immunity to Zen Headbutt, and OHKOes Electric-types like Alolan Raichu and Regieleki. Megahorn deals with Ogerpon-W, which greatly threatens Psychic's most common physical wall in Slowbro, while Zen Headbutt lets it clean Fighting teams late-game. Alternatively, Iron Boulder can choose to run Throat Chop to deal with Ghost-types more effectively or Iron Head to finish off Mega Altaria and OHKO Alolan Ninetales and Mega Diancie. Strong wallbreakers like Mega Gallade, Nasty Plot Deoxys-S, Choice Specs Tapu Lele, and Choice Band Victini support Iron Boulder by either greatly weakening or outright removing defensive walls like Celesteela, Archaludon, and Porygon2, which helps it clean Flying, Dragon, and Normal teams late-game. Entry has from Jirachi and Celebi are helpful to offset Iron Boulder's mediocre damage. Jirachi can pivot Iron Boulder in with U-turn, while Celebi can swap into Ground- and Water-types like Mega Swampert and Ogerpon-W. Mega Latias swaps into predicted Ground- and Grass-type moves and appreciates Iron Boulder weakening or removing Alolan Muk to attempt to set up a sweep with Calm Mind.

Choice Scarf (Rock).description: As an offensive check to Fighting-types that also compresses speed control by holding a Choice Scarf, outspeeding foes such as Choice Scarf Meowscarada, Choice Scarf Enamorus, and Regieleki, Iron Boulder is a solid ally for Rock teams. Zen Headbutt threatens foes such as Iron Valiant, Sneasler, and Mega Lopunny. Earthquake and Close Combat provide coverage to ease the matchup against certain foes, with the former hitting Jirachi, Alolan Muk, and Tapu Koko, while the latter handles foes such as Ferrothorn, Meowscarada, and Hydreigon. Entry hazards from Pokemon such as Mega Diancie and Shuckle can wear down foes to ease the act for Iron Boulder to KO them; the former can also help offensively handle Dark-types for Iron Boulder. Hisuian Arcanine and Ogerpon-C also can be offensive checks to foes that can force out Iron Boulder as it gets locked into an undesirable move by KOing a foe or causing an outpredicted switch, with the former covering Steel- and Grass-types and the latter checking Water- and Ground-types. These Pokemon also complement each other at overwhelming shared checks such as Iron Hands, Kommo-o, and Skarmory.
